He met us at our hotel in Sultanahmet-district and we had an exciting tour of old Istanbul. Rasim is extremely knowledgeable and converse in fluent English. He even assisted us buying a data-packet for our GPS from Turkcell. His arranged his associate in Ephesus, Özgür Kocabıyık, who took us on an unforgettable tour of ancient Ephesus and who was very helpful when my 83-year old father-in-law got lost among the ruins. I was glad I've decided on having a professional guide in Istanbul and Ephesus, and doubly so on choosing Istanbul Guide Services.
Great guide. Had a lovely time touring the Hagia Sophia. Excellent pace and content. Also very nice to be able to skip the long line!

visit to ayosophia in istanbul. Our guide introduced himself and we got into the mosque/museum very easily. He explained the history and pointed out the most interesting points on our tour round the church.He was most polite and answered our torrent of questions well. He told us if he did not know the answer and where to get the information. An excellent guide and we would strongly recommend him to others.

Made the visit to Istanbul very enjoyable. Rasim, the tour guide was fantastic!He is very knowledgeable of the history and present of Istanbul society. Always engaging and kind. We toured Hagia Sophia and the Blue Mosque with him.Find him and ask for his tour.
Excellent service. Excellent guide. Very informative and gave us some tips of how to be careful in Istanbul and also directed us to a good spot for a lunch and drinks.

Hagia Sophia tour with Rasim. Rasim was an amazing tour guide. He knew so much about the Hagia Sophia that it was fascinating to walk through the place with him. He knew the history and the architecture and the Christian and Moslem facets of the site. Just top notch!

Istanbul fantastic tour. We have had one of the most spectacular days ever. Rasim is the best guide in Istanbul , from start to finish he is so so professional. His knowledge is out of this world and he is so friendly, nothing is to much. He stayed with us all day and actually took me to a local Turkish barber so I could indulge in a special Turkish shave ! Rasim then finished off with a tour of the Grand Bazzar and helped us in the art of haggling !! After that helped us to our tram to the hotel. Rasim is the best I can guarantee.
Informative. Very interesting, full of anecdotes and little stories that made the visit to Hagia Sophia very insightful. The guide was punctual and adapted the visit to suit our requirements.
Tour guide in Istanbul. Having a tour guide around the Blue Mosque, Haiga Sophia and Hippodrome make our trip much more meaningful.

Tour of Hagia Sophia with Rasim Terzi. We met Rasim outside and he suggested it would be much better to visit with a guide and we agreed. He was certainly very knowledgable and spoke very clearly and with proper enthusiasm about the history of the building, in extremely good English. We spent over an hour with him and my understanding of the place is 100 times greater than if I had just wondered about and looked for myself. We all agreed he was fabulous value for money and were thrilled with the visit! Thank you Rasim.
Visit to Hagia Sofia. The guide was patient and explained well. He was knowledgeable and enthusiastic and kind. I would highly recommend the services.

One day visit of Istanbul. I met Rasim Terzi near Hagía Sophía. We spent six hours visiting the main attractions including the Egyptian Bazar where I bought some Safran and Curry spice.No line-up, directly to what is important. He adjusts his visit to your need and speed.Very handsome, he knows his stuff because he likes and learned history. I recommend to everyone.

Hagia Sophia better with a tour!. Rasim was an excellent guide. $30 USD for an hour that totally made our experience at the Hagia Sophia. It can definitely be much more appreciated knowing the history. Our guide was very friendly and funny. We are so glad we paid a little more to learn a ton about this unique architectural and religious gem.

Private Guide in Istanbul. We had a full day walking tour within the old city of Istanbul with Rasim Terzi. Rasim has a great command of English and he was engaging, informative and fun to be with. There were 6 of us in our group and he made sure that all were involved and no one was left out. If you are looking to learn about the history of Istanbul, see the major sights in the old city, and understand the background, call Rasim.

Tour Guide Istanbul -Sultanameh Rasim Terzi. Rasim is a wonderful guide, very helpfull, and has a very good knowledge about the history and wonderful places that Turkey has to offer. If there is one person that will asure that you will see and leave Turkey with a great memory, it will be Rasim thank you very much for your assistance during my stay at Turkey.

Hagia Sophia, Istanbul,Turkey. We hired him to bring us through the mosque..he was knowledgeable, polite and his English was very good. He delivered the tour in a way that was interesting and was able to point out many things that we would have otherwise missed..very enjoyable..
Tour with Rasim. Rasim did a great job! We loved the lunch spot he told us about as well for a local spot to eat after the tour. He is great for tours of the mosques or the overall town.
Great tour. Informative and interesting tour about the most iconic and famous landmarks. Really enjoyed it. Would recommend it :)
Worth it !!!. The information provided was more than enough and precise, it is obvious when a guide actually knows what he is talking about.Also the price for the tour was fare enough. Just great !
Really informative guide. Rasim was a really friendly guide who gave us an interesting background of the history of Istanbul and a tour of the Hagia Sophia.

A valuable guide to help understand all. Razim was very knowledgeable about the history of Istanbul and its surroundings. He made history come to life for us. At the end of the tour he even directed us to a wonderful restaurant where we enjoyed a delicious meal. I highly recommends Razim for any touring needs!!P.S. We felt very safe and secure and had no worries while site seeing. A couple of the buildings took extra security measures. Other than that, there were very few people and no lines-a great time to come!

Hagia Sophia Tour. Rasim gave us an English speaking tour of the Hagia Sophia museum. The tour was informative and covered a lot of things we did not know about the museum. I would recommend him to others wanting a tour

Tourist Guide Rasim. Our guide Rasim was very helpfull and well informed. He speaks well english. We enjoyed our visit to ayasophia because of the infirmation he provided to us. Thank you Rasim. We will sure ask for your help when we visit istanbul another time.

good private tour. we booked this private tour right before we entered to Hagia Sophia. we experienced this site totally different as we could ask whatever we want. the guide hat a HUGE knowledge also about Istanbul itself. the tour took about 45 minutes and was worth every penny. highly recommended!
Aya sofia. Our guide was very professional, knowledgeable and friendly. I would Highly recommend him for the tour.

The best!!!. hello ... istanbul visited with my wife and my daughter .. and when we came across the Hagia Sofia are faced with a long line .. here comes Rasim and moved all in 1 min ... wonderful , perfect ... the best investment made ... after all, why be taking pictures without knowing what you are doing if there is Rasim to help you understand what happens inside it ... worth it ... I recommend !!!

Knowledgeable and pleasant tour guide in Istanbul. We had Rasim as a 2-day tour guide in Istanbul, and, during rather short time, we managed to visit the main sites (Hagia Sophia, Blue Mosque, Ancient Hippodrome, Dolmabahce, Topkapi, Kaapalicarsi, and a few other). Rasim has extensive knowledge of Turkey's history and the time with him as a tour guide passes very pleasantly. I would highly recommend him for visitors to Istanbul.
Hagia Sophia Tour. Fascinating history was very well explained by our tour guide. Informative, friendly and professional. Highly recommended.
Ayasophia. I really liked the tour guide, Rasim provided us with an extensive information about the culture and the history

Istanbul Tour And Guide Services - Day Tours. The guide services brought what was a monument alive for us. We saw the story behind the features and the architecture - the guide was very knowledgable and answered all our questions. Besides, taking a guide reduced our time waiting in queues! I strongly recommend their services.

Brilliant tour in Istanbul's Old City. We are a group of six who went on Rasim's tour of the Hippodrome, Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia & Basilica Cistern in October. We had a brilliant time and the tour is worth every penny. Rasim is an excellent and knowledgable guide and gave us as much time as we wanted in each location. He was particularly effusive about the extraordinary Hagia Sophia (the "maestro in Istanbul's orchestra"). It was particularly great to have him accompany us there as there is very little information on plaques or otherwise so we would have missed so much had we been on our own. Worth noting also that both the Aya and the Cistern are museums and Rasim has priority at the queues which is another massive plus in this tour's favour.All in all we spent three and a half hours on the tour which was excellent value and Rasim's enthusiasm and knowledge continued from the first minute to the last.

Wonderful. Highly recommended. . We took Rasim as a guide on a whim. Approached by him at the entrance to Hagia Sophia and glad we did. He skipped the line for us and then the fun began. Hagia Sophia to us is the best attraction in Istanbul. Better than the adjacent Blue Mosque and up there with Topkapi. Rasim's commentary and guidance was great. He's articulate and knows the details on HS. The cost was well worth it for both skipping the line and also the intimate knowledge. The visit and commentary on the frescoes alone was worth the cost. Highly recommended.
Steve and Patti. Look for this guy. He is full of info and comical. Went into Sofia with him He saved us time in line and very smart guy
Aya sophia. Great place to visit, in front of it is the blue mosque which is good also. A lot of history and ward

Keenan family ssssight sseing day in Istanbul centre. Very enjoyable day. Our guide was very knowledgeable and structured in the way he presented the tour. Although we could have seen the sites on our own , our guide added information that we could not have picked up. This greatly enhanced the trip for us, particularly in the Hagia Sophia and the Blue Mosque.
Rashim's tour. An excellent tour. Very informative & good humoured. It made the trip very worthwhile. Thank you, very memorable

Excellent personalized tour of the AyaSophia. Rasim was very informative and patient with our many questions. He tailored the tour to our family, telling interesting stories with personal connections for a very reasonable small fee. I enjoyed the tour greatly and learned quite a bit--and so did our teenaged children! Thank you Rasim!

Razim was informative and enthusiastic. Razim met us as we were about to join a long queue to Hagia Sofia. Keen to skip the queue and get some information about the place we joined him and were pleased that we had. He set the historical scene of this amazing building, pointed out the mosaics we would probably have missed and explained how the church had been converted to a mosque and how it found itself as it is now. Well worth while. Thanks Razim.

A fabulous way to learn about Istanbul and it's fascinating history. We were met promptly at 9am outside our hotel by Rasim, our guide for the day.We started with the Hippodrom then moved on to the Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia and ended with the Basilica Cistern. Rasims' knowledge was incredible! There was never a question he couldn't answer and all four of us thoroughly enjoyed the day! It's advisable for women to carry a scarf to cover their heads and have their knees and shoulders covered when visiting Blue Mosque.

Hagia Sophia Day Tour. Rasim is nice and patient when we asked him some questions before commencing the tour. He was knowledgeable and insightful, pointing out key spots like the marble omphalion and shared useful tips like which angles were the best to capture pictures from 1st and 2nd floors. Overall a good experience.

Great Istanbul Tour!. We had a great time in Istanbul and we can thank Rasim for a very interesting 2 day tour. We had the chance of better knowing its monuments and its people through the useful insights and information provided by Rasim, in friendly and funny way. Thank you, Rasim!

Excellent tour guide. My two teenage daughters and I recently visited the AyaSofia with Rasim. He made the whole thing fun and interesting and much more enjoyable than if we had visited on our own. He knows his stuff and he doesn't charge the earth. I would recommend him any time!
Great Tour Guide. Informative and interesting ... most enjoyable tour of the old city . We toured the all the usual site around the Old City then enjoy lunch with our guide in a local restaurant.

Good Guide!!. Not like the other guides that charge you much more than the reasonable price! His pricing was good from the beginning!Furthermore, he is not in a hurry to go to other clients. He stays with you for how long you may need!

Thanks Rasim . We came to Istanbul with zero knowledge of Turkey and its history. Rasim was very patient with us. He was knowledgable and thoughtful. We are grateful to have Ransim as our tour guide. We would highly recommend him to our friends. In fact, when we met another couple that same evening we already recommended him to them. Thanks Rasim - keep up the great work.

Hagia Sophia. We had arrived on our cruise ship and made our way to see the Hagia Sophia.Whilst deciding to join the long queue we were approached by a Licensed guide called Rasimterzi who showed us his government licence. He said that he could jump the queue and get us in quickly with his guided tour and that we did not need to pay until the tour was finished. Our party of four were delighted with the tour and to learn of its incredible history. We would certainly recommend the services of this guide. We had no Turkish currency, only Euros and he was able to deal with this. A great guide at a great price.

Tour of Hagia Sophia. Rasimterzi proved to be an excellent guide. We were in the square outside Hagia Sophia looking at the que wondering if it was worth the effort when Rasimterzi approached us. He said "you only have to pay if you are happy with my service". Not only did we get to jump the que but the information he provided bought the history of this building alive. Well worth the fee. Thanks Rasimterzi!
Aghai Sofia. We enjoyed his guided tour very much. He was very polite and informative. He pointed out details that other guides have missed. Thank you
Tour Guide. one often feels dodgy about being ripped off by Tour Guides. Not the case here. Really good, really informative and good fun! No hesitations in recommending - this was great value.

Guide tour Hagia Sophia. I visited Hagia Sophia with my mother, one week ago and we chose to make a guide tour to see and learn more things. Rasim was our guide and he told us many interesting things about the museum's history and architecture. The tour was incredible and i recommend him as a guide for future visitors.
amazing tour of Hagia Sophia. The family and I were very fortunate to have Rasim as a guide in this beautiful building. He was congenial and informative and bought to life the history of the place.

Excellent tour guide!. Rasim picked us up at the cruise port and was on time both days. He is very pleasant and graciously answered our many questions about the history and culture of this beautiful city. We will definitely book him again on our next trip! I highly recommend him!

Walking tour of Istanbul. I thoroughly enjoyed Rasim's two day tour of Istanbul. He was full of interesting facts and very pleasant to be with. He was on time both days to pick us up and he was most gracious. I highly recommend him for anyone interested in knowing the real Istanbul. He will be booked again by us.

Istanbul and Cappadocia Tours with Rasim. I received Rasim's contact information from a work colleague who had used him for her family's 2014 visit to Turkey. I was planning a visit to Istanbul and contacted Rasim in regard to helping us with touring options. Rasim was very responsive and provided us with a suggested three day itinerary in Istanbul with the possibility of two side trips - Ephesus and Cappadocia. We corresponded via email and decided on two full days in Istanbul (covering all of the major sights, Hippodrome, Ayasofia, Topkapi Palace, Blue Mosque, Grand Bazaar, Spice Market, Dolmabahce Palace, The Cistern, Subway in second oldest tunnel in the world, Suleyman Mosque, etc. it was a huge amount to see in two days. But we were able to fit it all in (and more). Rasim took care of all of the tickets, picked us up at the hotel in a beautiful chauffeured van and took us back each evening. He lucked several historic restaurants for us to dine in and provided information on everything to do with Istanbul. We also took a Bosphorous Boat Tour (fantastic). Rasim is very knowledgeable of all of Istanbul's history and very interested in helping people learn. Rasim met us upon our arrival at Ataturk Airport with a transfer can to the hotel (invaluable as it was 1 am in the morning - and even better with a box of Turkish Delight in hand as a welcome gift). Rasim also arranged all of our transfer to Kayseri (transfer from hotel to airport, airline tickets and transfer from Kayseri Airport to our hotel (and back) - as well as a wonderful guide, Hande, who he partners with in Cappadocia. We had a full days tour with her of many sights in Cappadoccia. Wonderful experience. Rasim is very knowledgeable, accommodating and interested in his clients having a wonderful experience on their visit to Turkey. There are a few "secret" panaorana sights he may take you to which are really unbelievable!Once we picked our dates and sights to be seen he took care of everything else and for what I believe was a very reasonable fee.

Best 2 days in Istanbul. This was the best money spent anywhere! Rasim was an excellent tour guide, full of local knowledge and also went out of his way to take us to little known places. Taking us up to the rooftops to see a birds eye view of Istanbul and where Skyfall was filmed was the clincher for me. Thank you Rasim, will be back and will seek you out again.

Great tour with nice & knowledgable guide. Initially went inside Aya Sophia without guide - big mistake. Went back out and found Rasim. 100 Lire to 1 hour 2 people was a good investment. Highly reccomended.
Excellent guide. Excellent tour guide, good service and very knowable. If I had a chance, will request Rasim as tour guide again.

Excelent tour guide - look no further. We first contacted Istanbul Guide Services by calling the phone number provided. This was one day before our planned day to tour. Rasim Terzi answered and immediately agreed to see us the next day first thing in the morning. Good thing he has WhatsApp because it made it so easy to plan our tour. Rasim knows very good english and is fluent. He has the greatest spots to take pictures and will accommodate to any of your needs. He was really easygoing and well mannered which made our tour a blast. I greatly recommend his tour services. Do not hesitate in contacting him. You won't regret it.

One Day Tour of Istanbul. Our hotel, The Witt Istanbul Suites, organised at very short notice for a guide to show my wife & I around Istanbul. It is a vast city and at times some big queues to get into the main attractions. Rasim, our guide, provided us with a day to remember. We got to see all the main sites skiping the queues, got a great bit of history of the city and were greatly entertained by Rasim's stories.Razim is very professional who quickly understood our requirements for the day and set an agenda that met our interests. We could not have seen what we did without his guidance. Well worth it.

A wonderful surprise. We were not expecting to use a tour guide but Rasim convinced us that if we didn't like his tour of the Hagia Sophia, that we didn't have to pay him. Well he was truly a wonderful guide through the Hagia Sophia. He was able to explain the history and how it connected to locals like him. He did a great job breaking it down and making it easier to understand all of the changes throughout time. Would definitely hire him again!

Good & Quick Tour. Rasimm was very engaging and told us a fair bit of information. It was a short tour (45 minutes) at Hagia Sophia. We were happy we did it as it gave us a fair bit of information we wouldn't have found ourselves.Overall I would recommend Rasimm.

Two Days in Istanbul. My wife and I together with my son and his fiancee were on our way to Nepal and stopped in Istanbul for two days. We were lucky enough to meet and hire Rasim Terzi and spent our time together seeing historic Istanbul. I highly recommend him for his knowledge and attention to detail but more than anything else I recommend him for his friendly approach to helping us do what we wanted to do in the short time we had.

unforgettable istanbul trip. we enjoyed the time we spent with Rasimm,he is very kind,polite and intelligence guide .he has a very pleaseant personality and attitude, is easy to undersand .and is trustorthy.i would not hesitate to recommend Rasim if we back to istanbul.thank you so much .一次非常难忘愉快的旅行，感谢我们的导游RASIM，非常的耐心，有礼貌，对我们提出的问题非常仔细的回答，下次再去的话，我们会毫不犹豫的选择他。

Great Tour. We visited Istanbul while on a Mediterranean Cruise in May. I booked a tour for four that included the Hipodrome, the Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia, the Underground Cistern and Topkapi Palace. Rasim was great. He was very knowledgeable about all of the locations and was very receptive to my non-stop questions about anything and everything to do with life in Istanbul, We had an issue with the couple that joined us on the tour, but Rasim handled it well and it all worked out in the end. Many thanks to Rasim Terzi. We enjoyed the time we spent with Rasim. He is very polite and his knowledge is just great. Time went fast and we were always able to ask him our questions. Thank you very much - we will remember you and forward you to our friends.

Good Tour of Haggia Sophia. Rasim gave our family a tour of the museum that was informative. We had rented audio guides at Topkaki but found them lacking. Tour of Haigia Sofia and Cistern. I enjoyed my 2-3 hour tour with Rasim Terzi very much. I wish there would have been more opportunities, or suggestions for photography. However, I would recommend this tour service to my friends, family and colleagues. Perfect Guide Rasim. Rasim is so good guide.Because he has many intelligence, experienceSo he is perfect guide. And My family want to go Istanbul again.The most strong point is that he has kind personality.I like his guide tour :)

Recommend Rasim. Rasim picked usup from our hotel lobby and immediately began to give us historical information of the City. He is incredibly knowledgable and answered all our questions. He gave us time at each attraction to soak up the place on our own as well as giving anecdotes and best places to take photos!
Rasim Terzi. We only had a day in Istanbul on our cruise, booked Rasim by email on advice of friends excellent,knowledgable, user friendly guide.

I highly recommend Rasim. We just got back from a fabulous trip to Istanbul. While we also really enjoyed the adventures we had on our own, our one-day tour with Rasim was absolutely the best way to see the major sights. He showed us Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia, Hippodrome, Basilica Cistern, Topkapi and the Spice Market. He's very knowledgeable, doesn't tire of questions, and packed a lot into one day without rushing. He has a very pleasant personality and attitude, is easy to understand, and is trustworthy. Plan to be on your feet for many hours. Rasim is patient to take as many bathroom and rest breaks as you need.

Good guide, honest and easily understood. Rasim was a good clear guide who showed us features I had not known despite three previous visits. He charged a reasonable price and applied no pressure for extra at the end of thee tour. Thoroughly recommended.

Rasim -- great tour guide!. Rasim was very knowledgable, respectful and kind. He took us on a tour around Aya Sophia and the Blue Mosque, both very informative and interesting. He answered most of our questions and when he didn't know something he honestly said he wasn't sure about a certain fact -- we wished we had more time for him to show us around other temples/attractions. He gave us a very good vibe from start, not very sales-y/pushy. I highly recommend him if you are looking for a tour guide in Istanbul.
Great tour guide. I recently used Rasim for a full day tour of the major sights of Istanbul. He relayed his knowledge with charm and humour. I thoroughly recommend him.

When we come back we will use Rasim again. My wife and I are regular travellers having visited Antigua, Venice, Cornwall and Portugal as well as Istanbul in the first six months of this year. We decided to visit the Hagia Sofia on our first day in Istanbul but winced when we saw the queues. As we both hate queuing whenever we can we book speedy boarding etc. to avoid it. We discovered that a guide could take us straight through, we saw Rasim and engaged his services, we quickly realised how much a guide can bring dry old relics to life and give a view of the history which surrounds one. Rasim is also a proud Turk who seems to have the history of Turkey in his blood.After we parted company with him we realised that he was exactly what we needed for following days visit to the TopKapi museum. We emailed Rasim who agreed to meet us. He turned up with per ought tickets and eased our way into the museum, he again gave us an incredible insight into the world of the Ottomans.Rasim is also good company and a charming young man, on the day of our Topkapi visit he had just bought his first house we wish him luck and heartily recccomendations him as a guide to Istanbul antiquities.

Rasim Terzi: Guide, companion and agent. Rasim took my school group of 10 teenagers on a 2-day tour of the main Sultanahmed attractions, parts of the Bosphorus and some less well-trodden parts of local Istanbul. In particular, he found us a couple of superb restaurants. When we had some airport trouble on the way back, he was there to help us with extra transport, hotel and advice.

Super Tour!. Rasim Terzi is an awesome guide. Gave us a lot of interesting and funny information about the main sightseeing spots. Didn't want to involve guide in our trip when we arrived but didn't regret a single second. Highly recommend the man if you want to learn more about the city

Thank you Rasim Terzis!. On behalf of my Group from Norway, 25 pax in total visiting Istanbul in September 2013, thank you Rasim Terzis for arranging it all! The guiding in Istanbul and the private day cruise were both highlights for all of us! Every detail was arranged by mail from Norway and Rasim Terzis was always available with good service and friendly attitude from the first mail to the last minutes of the last excursion. friendly and very knowledgeable. I spent the weekend in Istanbul with my wife and by luck we found Rasim, he showed us all the main sites in one afternoon. He shared great insights not just about the site but also there historic context, he is fully licenses guide and told us he studied for four years about the history of Turkey and it clearly shows. We had a great afternoon and at very reasonable rates. Thank you Rasim you made the real difference for our visit.

a feedback to Rasim Terzi :). I was travelling to Istanbul on my own, just to wander around and see some great sights this marvelous city has to offer. I didn't plan on taking a guide so i was waiting in a line for tickets for Aya Sofia when a nice guy started a friendly conversation with me. I've found out he's a tour guide taking a break and he offered me a mini free tour of Aya Sofia. It was really nice of him that he chose to spend his break like that instead on coffee or tea, as he said :) I'm a fine art student, so it was a big plus for me that he focused on mosaics first, but he really mentioned most of the important sights of this grandiose basilica/mosque/museum, which made my visit far more interesting. All the best regards from Serbia :)

Rasim - a great guide. I spent a day in Istanbul last week. Rasim came to pick me up from the airport. He was very knowledgeable and helpful. I found him very flexible and was able to adapt to my changing requirements quickly and took me to places I wanted. He was warm ,hospitable and honest.He spent in Lira for me and kept a clean account. He helped me with my bags ,took me to a classic hamam ,and we had lunch together in a street side restaurant.I would recommend him and his services to any one. Rasim will do even better if he improved his English.

Rasim = First-class customer service even after we left Istanbul!. We found Istanbul Tour & Guide Service on Tripadvisor. Our guide, Rasim Terzi, was a joy to be with. He truly gave us a "behind-the-scenes" look at Istanbul, including taking us through an old neighborhood and onto the rooftop of a building (literally) for a great view in the city! He's also a "foodie" and shared his love for food with us by taking us to several of his favorite local places (for fresh Turkish Delight, homemade ice cream and a great Turkish lunch). The day felt like it was spent with a warm family friend, rather than with some of the bored, "canned" guides we've been stuck with in the past. Rasim not only helped us with some shopping missions while we were in town, but he also went to a store THREE TIMES after we were back in the States to help us deal with some problems we had with a lamp we bought!! That's what I call going above and beyond! He'll be the first we call when we're planning to return to Turkey.

"Locally Istanbul" Tour Guiding Services. Locally Istanbul.com Tour Guiding Services were recommended to us by our hotel, The House Galatasaray, in Istanbul and we could not have been more satisfied. Run by two recent university grads, these entrepreneurs aim to show tourists the best not only of historic Istanbul but the heart of the contemporary city. Being only 4 enabled us to take local transport and to visit hidden sites, restaurants, antique dealers,designers and shops that would not be accessible to larger groups. Erk Erkaya showed us the best of European Istanbul as well as fascinating aspects of the Asian side and a comprehensive tour through the Golden Horn. He also guided us through the most elaborate to the simplest of great Turkish cuisine. This is one guide you will want to show you his Istanbul. He guided us over 3 1/2 days.
Rasim TERZI / 4 days in istanbul. Rasim was the perfect guide for our 4 day trip to istanbul, and he gave 25 people a valuable insite in both history and the historic buildings. Recomended!

Excellent Tours. We met Rasim when we were standing in line at the Hagia Sofia. We took him up on his offer for a private 45 minute tour. The tour ended up being closer to an hour. It was a great experience. Rasim provided a well planned tour with excellent background information. We would not have spent as much time or enjoyed our visit as much if we had just toured through on our own. Later that evening we decided to go to the Topkapi palace the next morning. I emailed Rasim asking him if he was available to take us on a tour of the palace. Luckily, he was available. He took us on a 2.5 hour tour of the palace including the Harem. Again, we were very pleased with the insight that he provided into Ottoman cultural traditions, area history and the palace itself. Money well spent!

We were very happy with our guide Rasim. We were so pleased with our guide Rasim, he was very nice and make our trip a good experience and makes everything so exciting and keeps you captivated..Thanks Rasim!

Rasim Terzi was a great tourguide!. Rasim Terzi has a real interest in explaining to you about the heritage of Istanbul. He makes everything so exciting and keeps you captivated. We were very happy to have had him as our guide. Well done Rasim!

Needs improvement. Rasim took us to:-Blue Mosque-Hippodrome-Hagia Sofia-Topkali PalaceHe was very nice and pleasant, no complaints there. However, he was not very energetic at all. He also just grazed the surface of every description of all locations. We could have easily gotten the same info from a basic guide book. It just wasn't very exciting at all and no one was impressed with his tour. Pros: no wait it lines, everything was organized for us, and we essentially made our own schedule and went at our own paceCons: you pay money for a mediocre tour, I would have rather paid more for a guide who is fun and very knowledgeable. Rasim got several facts wrong, we questioned him on them, and he changed the story. This simply should not happen from an experienced tour guide.I am not quite sure why everyone else had such great reviews... perhaps we wanted a more in depth tour than others? Perhaps he had an 'off' day? I would give a 2 our of 5 for the quality of the tour, but bumped it up to a 3 out of 5 since Rasim was nice.

Very good service at Hagia Sophia. While waiting at the entrance of Hagia Sophia we met Rasim Terzi and he explained us the advantage of hiring a guide. He was clear and the price was OK so we hired him for a short tour of the Hagia Sophia. He gave us a quick overview and a good start for our own exploration afterwards. Besides this he got us out of the queue and past the ticket office very quickly. Rasim is a very good guide, honest and straightforward. I would strongly advice him.

Great tour guide!. In April we spent two half-days with Rasim on our first trip to Istanbul. First, my experience in booking the tours with Rasim was very good. He was very prompt in answering my email enquiries and also very helpful with letting me know in advance what the weather forecast was so my family and I were prepared with umbrellas, and with tweaking my proposed itinerary so that it made the most sense. Rasim also sent me a reminder about bringing my youngest child's passport to ensure she had a reduced entry ticket fee for some of the major sites -- I'm sure I would not have remembered that without the reminder! He was easygoing about the currency we paid in which also made it simple for us.We visited the Topkapi Palace and Hagia Sofia the first day. Rasim was very knowledgeable about their history and was sure to point out important aspects of both, and also gave us time at our own pace to enjoy the sites. (Don't miss either of these sites - they were definitely the highlights of Istanbul for me.) He was interested in any questions we had, and if he didn't know the answer was not afraid to say so - and he also followed up with an email for me later with some information that he had discovered. As another reviewer mentioned, he avoided long lines by timing our entries as well.The second day we visited the Blue Mosque, the underground cistern (my 16 year old son's highlight, and as we were quite interested in these cisterns Rasim detoured to show us a few more!), the hippodrome, the university, Suleymaniye Mosque, a few views of the ancient aqueduct, and finally the Grand Bazaar.Rasim recommended two GREAT and affordable restaurants with terrific atmosphere for us for lunch - Seyhmuz Kebap Evi and Sultanahmet Koftecisi. He also brought us to his favorite ice cream place - where we returned again later that afternoon!

Rasim Terzi was awesome!. Rasim was our tour guide for a day in Istanbul and was fantastic. My two daughters and I found him very knowledgeable and helpful. The best part was since he has so much experience dealing with the tourist population, he actually reversed our tour to what people normally do. By doing this we avoided standing in long lines and got into sites that are difficult to navigate when crowded (the Palace), before the crowds. He also had tickets ready for us so we didn't have to stand in line for those and then stand in line AGAIN for admittance. He saved us many hours of idle waste. The lines for the museums can be very long. We were in Istanbul over the Easter week, so naturally it was crowded. Still we got to see all the sites and had a wonderful day! Try to get Rasim!

2 days Istanbul tour with Rasim. My wife and I spent the Easter Weekend in Istanbul and spent two days with Rasim as our guide. He is a really good guide. He brought us around Istanbul visiting the ancient hippodrome, blue mosque, hagia sophia, the underground cistern, tokapi palace and the grand bazaar on the first day and suleymaniye mosque, rustempasha mosque, spice market and the wonderful bosphorous tour on the second day. He also recommended places for dinner and shops to buy baklava and Turkish delight which we woundn't have foud by ourselves. He also arranged and adapted the trip to help us safe precious time as Istanbul was really busy and packed during the Easter weekend.He knows the Turkish history really really well and gave us lot's of interesting information. We have a wonderful two days with Rasim and would recommend it to everyone. Thank you Rasim.

Rasim Terzi great guide. Rasim Terzi was our guide for our visit to the Aya Sofia. He gave us lot's of interesting information. We've had a great tour and the Aya Sofia is worth visiting. If you need a good guide, ask for Rasim!
Guide in Turkey. I met Rasim in my first trip to Turkey, in 2008, in Kusadasi. He is passionate about his work and eager to answer tourists' questions about the sights visited.

Quick City Tour Of Istanbul. I met Rasim through reviews on Trip Advisor as I had a short stop over in Istanbul (5 Hours). What a great guide I travelled alone and was nervous as a single female he however picked me up from the airport and arranged for me to visit the ancient hippodrome, blue mosque, hagia sophia and the underground cistern before coming back to the airport with me. He is a wealth of knowledge with a passion for Istanbul he advised me on what to wear, what the weather will be and even carried enough Turkish Lira so that I could just simply pay him in Euro's at the end instead of changing money. I had a wonderful and interesting morning. Thank you Rasim keep up the great service, I wish you many years of success as a guide.

Rasim is the best guide. Rasim was an excellent choice for guide during our stay in Instanbul.We were queueing in front of Hagia Sofia when Rasin came and provide his service. After that he passed us trough the queue without loosing time. Onece we were in we found that Rasim was very knowledgable knowing everything about ancient history. And also he is very amusing, the tour with hem was really great, I recommend Rasim's services to everyone which want to explore Istanbul.

Rasim Terzi is a great guide!. We only had just over an hour to see the Hagia Sophia and Rasim came to ask if we would like a tour. He got us past the long line immediately and saved us a ton of time. Once we entered, we found Rasim to be extremely knowledgeable about the history of the Hagia Sophia as well as witty and interesting. I can highly recommend him as a guide and we will hire him again on our next visit.

Rasim provided an excellent tour!!. Rasim was an excellent tour guide for our family of five. We had a full day in the old city, and Rasim's knowledge of the key sites as well as how he planned the day led to one of the best days we have ever had with a private tour. We had an age range of 10-18 with our children, and Rasim was able to appeal to all and answer any of our questions across a wide range of topics. His knowledge of history was impeccable making the day incredibly enjoyable and informative. He also took us to a great restaurant for lunch!! I would highly recommend Rasim and Istanbul Tour and Guide Services.

Great Hagia Sophia Guide. Rasim did an excellent job as our family's guide for the Hagia Sophia. My husband and I are expats in Istanbul and have hired several guided tours when we have visitors. Rasim was one of the best tour guides we've hired!I was particularly impressed with the way Rasim took the time to give a brief history of Istanbul before even entering the Hagia Sophia. He explained why one needs to know a bit about Istanbul's history to understand the significance of the building. Rasim certainly knows his history and he conveys it in an interesting and engaging way. He was very courteous and professional, and even slowed down the tour to accommodate my husband's elderly mother. We highly recommend him!

Rasim Terzi is the best!. Rasim guided our small group to the Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia, the Archeological Museum, and TopKali Palace. His tour was very informative. Throughout the day we asked lots of questions on a wide range of subjects and his knowledge of history as well current Istanbul politics and policies was broad and deep. All that and he's a very nice man too!

2 Days with Rasim - well worth it!. My wife and I spent two days in Istanbul with Rasim guiding. He is punctual, knowledgable, fun and adaptable. He has great insights on Istanbul history, culture and cuisine. We strongly recommend him.

Tour of Istanbul. I booked Rasim for a day long tour of the highlights in Istanbul. It was our first time in Istanbul, and we wanted an overview of the sights with a local.(There were 3 of us in our group- late 30’s) Rasim arrived promptly at our hotel to collect us. We were staying in the Sultanahmet district, so it was very close to all of the sights on our itinerary. Rasim arranged our day as to miss as much of the crowds as possible, advising us to see the Blue Mosque first, so on and so forth. With that said, he was very accommodating to switch the Grand Bazaar to the end of the day so that I could maximize my shopping time! One of the benefits of having a personal guide was not only the flexibility of what we wanted to see, but as a licensed guide, we were able to skip many of the very, long lines. I would recommend Rasim to any of my friends or family visiting the city for the first time.

Old Istanbul. On Aug the 17th, 2012, we had the pleasure of taking a private tour of the Old part of Istanbul. Our guide's name was Rasim Terzi aqnd we booked him through a site called Viator, which lists liscenced guides from all over the world. Surprisingly, the cost of a private guide for 4 people was less than if we had taken a group tour. Rasim gave us a tour of Hagia Sophia, the Blue Mosque and Topkapi Palace including the must see Harem. He has an extensive knowledge of the history of these ancient sites and was able to answer our many questions. The tour was outstanding and we have Rasim to thank for making this a most memorable day.

Sultanahmet Square. Just a brief note to thank Rasim for his outstanding services as our tour guide. As a member of a group of people from the State of Maine in the United States, it was a pleasure to travel throughout Turkey and to witness the dramatic and positive changes that are taking place Our visit to many of the wonderful sites in Istanbul was made even more pleasant with our tour of the Sultanahmet Square guide by Rasim Terzi...he was extremely pleasant, knowledgeable, and provided our group with a real insight into the history of not only the Square by of many other tourist sites and questions that we had about Istanbul and its people. I would highly recommend his services to those who are visiting Istanbul.

thanks for everythings rasim:). I want to talk about tourist guide in istanbull and my darling. we decided to visit to istanbul.First of all we couldnt know anything about istanbul. so we search on the net few days.Lastly we decided to go with our guide books which about istanbul and historical places, museums, and night lifes.However when we arrived over there. Yours really be sure, books wont be enought for sightseeing, almost everywhere crowd and traffic terrible.We fastly decided how can do our best holiday, we have already checked web adresses about istanbul. we called rasim at sultanahmet area. really! 5 minutes later he was the with us.we made 4 days tours with rasim. l can advise ( sultanahmet area, sultanahmet mosgue, hagia sophia, topkapi palace, dolmabahce palace, prince islands, bosphorus boat tour( really you can find cheap price boats but rasim find for us best quality, comfortable )

Great Tour in a Great City by an Awesome Guide. My wife and I were on a Eastern Mediterranean cruise on the MSC Magnifica. Not wanting to fight the crowded overpriced tours offered by the cruise, we booked with Rasim at Istanbulguideservices.com. The booking process was easy and the tour itinerary was flexible. We arrived in Istanbul less than happy as the airline lost our luggage and we had to spend the whole cruise in the same clothing. We were less than impressed but our mood lifted when Rasim met us at the dock as planned. He was there early with the vehicle and driver waiting. We went to all the sights and were impressed by the knowledge and passion Rasim has for his city and the history surrounding it. It was great having our own vehicle and we were able to beat most of the crowds from the cruise. Rasim also took us to a great restaurant for authentic Turkish cuisine.Due to the ship being late arriving in Istanbul, our planned tours had to be modified. Rasim was great in accommodating all that my wife and I wanted to do in order for us to get the most out of the tour-he also made sure that we beat the Istanbul rush-hour traffic to arrive at our ship on time.Also, as a side note, Rasim contacted us when we arrived home to make sure that we had received our lost luggage. He even provided phone numbers for the Turkish baggage handlers in case we wanted to try and phone them in Turkey to track down our bags.All in all we owe him a lot of gratitude and thank him for a wonderful and memorable day in Istanbul.
Hidden gem. Far from tourists and giant busses, if you come to this mosque, complete silence will fall upon you. Small and historical, it is quite great I felt great for coming there.
A small historical mosque. This is a small historical church that was converted into a mosque after the conquest of Constantinople. A good place to visit.
Amazing Place . Really amazing and awesome and shows the greatest history of Islam. Lovers of arts they will like this place a lot

Exquisite . This 'small but perfectly formed' ex-church and now mosque was empty when we arrived and it was an extremely peaceful time that we had examining and enjoying the beauty of it - well worth a visit.

Very nice church. vey close to arasta bazar. The former church - now tzami- is very nice in the interior. Simple but elegant. With big but delicate marble stylus- called kionokrana. The outside of the church reminds so much Agia Sofia. Very well preserved. After visiting the church walk around to the neighborhood. Old but very beautiful buildings. Aroma of another era.
islamic architecture and Christians architectury come together.. I love this place because it was a church that changed to a mosque. The paintings that was belongs to byzantine was great.

Small Ayia Sophia. I believe that is the name on the map. It is worth the visit if you have some extra time. Few visitors there so not crowded. You might get the (payed and unplanned) tour by an old man speaking pretty good english and quite knowledgable of the history of the church and not only.

Tranquil hidden gem. Had fantastic days going to little hidden site which is older than the Ayasofya. Not many tourist know about it so there was no hussle or bussle, beautiful set and mantained excellent tranquil place to visit.

Beautiful building and peaceful area.. I stayed quite near tho this place. Almost each prayer time, i came here to pray. It used to be a church before converted to mosque. The people who come here to pray i guess they stay nearby. The imam and the jemaah were very nice and welcoming. Love the interior wall decoration.
BEAUTIFULL ARCHITECTURE. The place is great to visit, and shows a lot of mixture between CHRISTIAN and ISLAMIC architecture. you need to buy your ticket to enter and wait in along row of visitors .

Amazing. This is like a small replica of Saint Sophia. However, I was told that it was build before the Great Saint Sophia. This beautiful structure recently renovated dates back to Byzantine era as an Orthodox church, only after the Ottoman era it was converted to a mosque. A must see when you are in Sultanahmet district.
Small Ayasofya . Almost same to Ayasofya. Nice architectural mosque which was believed to be a church. The area is very simple and less visitors.

Old and beautiful former church . Very beautiful mosque with a long history as an orthodox church. Some traces all still found from 6th century from the relieves of pillars. There were kind man who told as about this church history and also times after Ottoman Empire.

Somewhat hidden historical church, now mosque. We used to know Hagia Sophia. Not many people know about Kucuk Aia Sophia, or Small Hagia Sophia. The former church is located down from Sultanahmet towards the seashore. It is not so glorious as the Hagia Sophia, but it is interesting to see its interior and trace remainings of the original church.

Little gem of a place. We visited this lovely little Mosque. Very beautiful. We met a man who showed us round as an informal guide. We realized he would expect payment, but he was interesting and answered our questions. Just be aware you might inadvertently start a conversation that leads to paying for a guide you didn't plan for. The also was a church before it became a mosque and is very beautiful. As it is a functioning Mosque there is no fee, but a donation box.

Always a highlight. Little Hagia Sophia (SS Sergius and Bacchus) was always an atmospheric place but is even better since the recent restoration. Great to combine with a visit to (the thousand years younger) Sokullu Mehmet Pasha Mosque, both only 5 minutes walk from the Hippodrome.

Oasis of calm. Even with the painters at work on the interior nothing could dispel the serene atmosphere of this delightful and very old building in a traditional part of Sultanahmet, a few minutes walk from the Blue Mosque toward the Sea of Marmara.

Peaceful and Beautiful Respite from Busy Istanbul. Tucked away off the major tourist center of Sultanahmet, the Kucuk Ayasofya Camii (Little Ayasofya Mosque) is about a 7-8 minute walk from the main square. Built by Justinian in the 6th century, it is said to be the prototype for the much-larger Aya Sofia in Sultanahmet Square.The 7-8 minute walk will take you along well-traveled streets lined with a mix of shops and restaurants catering to both tourists and locals, and a few hotels.It was converted (as the Aya Sofia was) to a mosque after Constantinople fell to Mehmet the Conquerer in 1453. Kucuk Ayasofya is a working mosque; women are required to dress appropriately with headscarves; shoes are removed in the little alcove just inside the entrance - there's a convenient cubby-hole system along one wall to place your shoes until you are ready to leave. You'll see an older ablution fountain with a (non-working) hand pump on the inside - the current washing fountains are outside the structure in the courtyard.Elements of when the Greeks held the city are evident in the 'Greek key' architectural details, and you can climb the short flight of stairs to a platform and overlook the interior. Not many tourists, therefore very peaceful inside. Shades of cream and blue abound, and the interior design work of carvings, tiles, and paintings are not as overwhelming as some of the larger mosques. The cream and blue colors reminded us of Greece; as this was a Greek church for centuries, perhaps this is color scheme was an intentional choice.We can't say for certain if there was an entrance fee - we were so taken in by how lovely the mosque is - we recall leaving a 10 TL each donation (as of June 2016, ~$3.42), but due to our limited understanding of Turkish were not sure if that was an entrance fee or not.In many ways, we found Kucuk Ayasofya more beautiful than the better-known Aya Sofia because it is smaller, much less crowded, and it you can get much closer to see the beautiful tilework and architectural details. And, as long as there are no prayer services, you can sit as long as you like and enjoy the serenity.

Beautiful Byzantine Church now a Mosque again.. This is so like a small version of Aya Sofya, it was an obvious name to adopt ('kucuk' meaning small) and obvious that a story would develop that it was a model for the actual Aya Sofya. It is a beautiful example of a 6th century church, dedicated to 2 Christian Roman soldiers, although all the Byzantine mosaics and frescos were removed in the 16th century when it was converted into an Ottoman mosque. But the beautiful pillars and their intricately carved capitals, and the Greek friezes above them were left undamaged, either by the Ottomans or the more recent renovations. Although technically a museum since the Republic was formed in 1922, it seems to have again become a mosque after renovation, meaning ladies must now cover up and making viewing tricky on a Friday But definitely worth a visit. Make sure you go upstairs (but be careful on worn steps).

Underrated. It's not far from the Blue Mosque, and you get to wander around Sultanahmet on the way there. Originally a Greek Orthodox Church and also known as Little Hagia Sophia, it has the exterior architecture and some interior details of a church, but it's currently a Mosque and has Ottoman designs inside. As well as being beautiful, it's very peaceful and quiet

A gem that shouldn't be missed. If you are interested in Byzantine churches and architecture, make time to see this 6th-century church. You can walk to it from Hagia Sophia. Originally dedicated to Saints Sergius and Bacchus, it was built by Justinian before Hagia Sophia. It has many beautiful details. Be sure to climb the stairs to the gallery and look at the Greek inscriptions.
Visit this place ... Amazing place and amazing atmosphere .. Get the chance to sit beside one of the oldest spots in istanbul and also enjoy the service ;)

Don't Miss This when you leave Topkapi Palace. Little Hagia Sophia is stripped to the bone but because of that you see more. The dome, the balcony, the pulpit all seem to make the place appear more real that Hagia Sopia.

Not too many visitors. This is a transformed mosque, from an orginally in 6.th century built church. It is not on the main tourist routes, so if you get in there are not too many tourist. The original architecture is still to be seen. The locals call it "Little Aya Sofia".

A fine example of Byzantine-meets-Ottoman. We began our explorations today at the Kȕçȕk Ayasofya Mosque, built in the Sixth Century by the Byzantine Emperor Justinian as a church honoring Saints Sergius and Bacchus, the Fourth Century Roman Christian martyrs who appeared to the emperor in a dream. Because the “Little Hagia Sophia,” as it is known, retains the architectural features of the original church, it struck us as an example of the Ottoman practice of re-purposing Christian religious structures, often whitewashing over mosaics and frescoes, rather than tearing churches down to build mosques. Whether this practice demonstrated tolerance or frugality, it was a treat to see the surviving examples of Byzantine art.

Astonishing marble work. We were alone in this wonderful building on a holiday weekend in May. It is not more than 20 minutes walk from the crowded areas of Aya Sofia and The Blue Mosque but seems virtually unvisited. Anyone with any interest in architecture and history would be well advised to visit. The detailed marble work is of astonishing quality and in marvellous condition for its great age. I urge you to take the trouble to find it.

Another hidden gem. As with many architectural gems of Istanbul, the Kucuk Ayasofya (or small Hagia Sophia) is located out of the way. I wouldnt have known about its existence if not for an impromptu decision to join a tour to Topkapi Palace which includes a detour to the Kucuk Ayasofya.This mosque was a church built as a mock up for the real stuff hence some similarities in terms of architecture with the Hagia Sophia.
nice. nice place and important things its free :) if you near there also you can go visit.... nice to be there...

Old "Little Sophia". This ancient Church is now a mosque, but the beautiful greek words of holy Scripture (Bible ) are still carved in the facade inside. It is small and down by the shore of the Sea of Marmara, but it is really beautiful and peaceful. It is worth seeing and spending the time to walk there. From the tramline it is an 8 minute walk downhill.

Little Ayasofya. This Byzantine era church, built in the 6th century, like most other churches here was converted into a mosque.The single minaret mosque now stands just beyond the railway line along Kennedy Caddesi. I had to figure out a way to get to it on my morning walk because I found myself on the wrong side of the railway line. Nice church in typical Byzantine style architecture.

Away from the crowds. Little Aya Sofya (formerly SS Sergius and Bacchus church), is out of the tourist area (sorry not in Topkapi Palace area, that was a mistake). It was built at the same time as its big sister, and provides an interesting comparison for architecture buffs.

A miniature Ayasofya. A little church built by Justinian and Theodora just before they built the much grander Aya Sofya. After Constantinople was overrun by the Ottomans this small church was turned into a mosque. It is still a working mosque so it is still a matter of shoes off and dress modestly. We were fortunate to be there when the caretaker was vacuuming the carpets and he showed us a few things that we would have missed ourselves. The church is just down the hill from the Blue Mosque.
Small yet nice. The Kucuk hagia sophia was walking from our Sofia apartments. there is nothing much to see though. All the mosques in Istanbul look the same and are beautiful.
Excellent. Huge giant church which was converted to mosque and now converted it into museum. Neat and clean Area.

a place to visit after blue mosque visit , nice interiors for good photos and memories for ever. he detailed workmanship and great beauty are impressive plus we ended up with our own personal guide who had visited in the past and was more than happy to point out hidden treasures.
ayasofya. ayasofya ,a place to visit after blue mosque visit , nice interiors for good photos and memories for ever

Beautiful old church. A must see when you are in Istanbul. The detailed workmanship and great beauty are impressive plus we ended up with our own personal guide who had visited in the past and was more than happy to point out hidden treasures.

A Little Gem of a former Church now a Mosque. This little Church was one of the first churches built by Justinian around the early 500's AD. It also shows the the emergence of the new and distinctive Orthodox style of Architecture. (Also its is very near President Kennedy road which I found amusing for some reason.) Its dome for some reason was very hypnotic to me. I am glad that I know of it.

A small but very nice place. We were the only visitors on a Saturday morning. It is a small but very quiet place and it is worth a visit if you are in the neighborhood. We stayed about 10-15 minutes.It is free but we were asked to make a donation.
Magical!. I went on a Sunday morning early-ish (10h30) and had the mosque all by myself! It was truly magical! It's small and intimate and absolutely stunning. Highly recommend.
beautiful little mosque. these little mosques are just great masterpieces. Is just like when you walk into Rome and find smal unknown churches that are so nice and breathtaking

A small but magnificent building. Not the typical tourist attraction in Istanbul but it is just as incredible as others. It is very beautiful inside out. It is not crowded so you can a peaceful time appreciating this 1600 year old mosque

Great!. We visited this mosque with our group and guide. Perfect place, absolute silence and peace. No mosaics inside but you can see the columns and cross on them. Has a beautiful garden with little shops of old books and ceramics.

A charming Church - Mosque. This is another great sample of Byzantine art and architecture. If you have extra time in the Old Town, do visit this one. It is functioning as a mosque today. Be aware of the prayer times before visiting.

Must see; way older than Hagia Sofia and no lines!. This is a lovely little mosque that is much much older than the "Big" Hagia Sofia. It, too, as also a church that was converted to a mosque. However, the "little" Hagia Sofia is still a functioning mosque. It is set back away from all the major sites and has no line. It is quite small but pretty and has a lot of history. A lot of the original artwork/decoration was covered when it became a mosque. As with most mosques in Istanbul, you will be asked to cover your head/shoulders with a scarf (if you are a woman) and possibly you legs if they are bare (men and women) and to remove your shoes, all before you can enter the mosque. There was no entrance charge.

a church older than present st.sophia. it s just 10 minutes away from sultanahmet mosque on the sea shore direction and its one of the most important church in the city from early Byzantiun period.it s still being used as a mosque .you must use your imagination in order to recapture the the beautiful original conditions of the walls that were once revetted with marbles and mosaics.Beautiful marble columns and their capitals sculptured like lace work is trult amazing.its one of the must see places in istanbul.

Beautiful Byzantine Architecture. Due to a poor map, we had a hard time finding this mosque. But the former church stands only about a 10-minute walk from Aya Sofya. I think it is worth going out of one's way to visit because of the Byzantine architecture and the building's history. The red-brick structure features an imposing dome and an irregular octagon shape. Inside, big columns remain from the building's days as a church. Justinian and his wife, Theodora, built the little church at some point between 527 and 536, just before Justinian's massive Aya Sofya went up. The minaret and madrasah, now used for other purposes, date from the church's conversion to a mosque in 1500.The mosque proved to be extremely quiet. Only one other person joined us inside. We took about 10 minutes to look around and then left for the small tea room that occupies part of the former madrasah. The tea was good; the WC proved to be in deplorable condition.

Kucuk Ayasofya Camii (Little Hagia Mosque). Marvelous architecture, peace & calm atmosphere. Located in Kucuk Ayasofya Dist., very much close to Meydan Arkasi, st.# 15, Sultanahmet, Istanbul-34122, Turkey.

Small old church converted into mosque. Unless you got time to spare after you visited the major sites, this ex-church converted to mosque is nice to visit for as a peaceful alternative to other historical sites. Nice courtyard and a ultra-friendly cat awaits you there.

Church and mosque. Originally The Church of Sergios and Bachos. converted into mosque but you can see the traces of the church! It's really clear to see the Byzantine columns and the inscription all above the columns.

Amazing place!. Outstanding architecture, the size of everything inside, ranging from pillars, domes, candelabra is surprising and incredible. Very busy though. Try to be there well before 10am and preferably on a weekday.
The little Hagia Sofia. When you see this mosque it has similar architecture remeniscent of Hagia Sofia . The architect who did this is the same architect who designed Hagia Sofia
Hagia Sophia in miniature.. This small wonder of church architecture from the Byzantine period is certainly worth a visit. Is easy to find with the city map. Visit it every time I am in Istanbul.
Little Haghia Sophia. Kucuk Ayasofya Camii is a small mosque close to the Blue Mosque in Sultanahmet. Beautiful inside and well worth a visit. Open daily.
Small Hagia Sofia. already the walk from big Hagia Sofia is worth the trip. cute little mosque with nice decoration and beautiful carpet

Little Aya Sofia Mosque... A Little Gem near the Blue Mosque. This was a 2 minute walk from our hotel so we visited it a couple of times. Though opening hours state 9:30 onwards, when we got there around 10:00, there was no one there to open the mosque though the garden/cafe area was open.We made another visit a day or so later and were invited in. Small mosque but beautifully decorated. We were allowed to go upstairs where usually the muezzin (the person who makes the call to prayer) stands and take a few photographs from different angles.Usually very quiet as we didn't see many tourists there, so very different from the Blue Mosque in that way!If you're visiting the Blue Mosque, make your way here after (about a 5 minute walk) - it's worth it!
Worth a detour to visit. A nice little attraction tucked away from the main tourist trail of Istanbul. It is now a mosque, but was once a church. The neighbourhood around is also nice

Little Hagia Sophia. Close to the ruins of Great Palace and Sphendon, former Byzantine Orthodox church. Very cosy part of the city. Now is serving as a mosque. still you can see the columns and ornamentations.

A church turn Mosque turn museum. If you want to see where the Emperors of Rome were crowned..then you must visit this site. You will also see beautiful Christian motives super imposed by Islamic writings
Beautiful sight. if time to visit only one mosque in Istanbul, this is the one. The architecture, the mix of Catholic architecture and Islam is superb. The old wall mosaics are worth the visit.

One of the best places in Istanbul. Just 5 minutes downhill from the Hippodromes, this astonishing building, formerly a Byzantine church and now a mosque is breath-taking. The classical Justinian Byzantine Architecture may be admired here and if you can read Greek you may still read the inscription around the internal walls. Visit in the afternoon and take some time to also drink a cup of coffee or tea in the nearby places and admire the building. Ask the keeper to lift the carpet as you enter the main hall and see the original floor.

Delightful. "Little Hagia Sophia" was built in 527AD although constructed some five years before Hagia Sophia, the church earned its nickname because of its resemblance to the Great Church. The buildings are similar in design but each has their own individuality. The church has an irregular plan.Four octagonal pillars, around the top of which are inscriptions that honour Justinian, his wife Theodora and St Sergius, support the vaulted central dome. The gallery above affords an excellent view of the interior which was decorated with coloured marble facings and lavishly decorative golden mosaics. The church was converted to a mosque shortly after Mehmet's conquest of the city.The mosque is located beyond the southern end of the Arasta Bazaar, along Ayasofya Cadd. It can also be accessed from the sea front, past the Bucoleon Palace, via a tunnel under the railway line.

Stroll down the street and meet a gem. The Kücük Ayasofya Camii (als known as SS Sergus and Bacchus) is known as a precursor to the big Hagia Sophia.It is a building from around AD 530. The interior is sheer magic!

A hidden gem!. You may have a little bit of difficulty in finding this gem, but when you do, you will truly enjoy the structure and the serenity of its grounds. As a builder, I truly appreciate the imperfections of the structure i.e. the mezzanine construction. @instabuilt
Wonderful hidden mosque. You need to look for it, but once you find it is really worth, full of bizantine details in capitels and signs
Great. While you are in ayasofya many interesting points needs to be stop at in details reading the history and learning many things
A quick trip. It is a great place to visit but very limited in appeal. You can really take your time and still cover it in just 30 mins max.

A former orthodox church. The church was dedicated to the Saints Sergius and Bacchus,but turned into a camii at the Ottoman Empire. It is a small but lovely church, which although is not so famous to the tourists, however it is worth visiting.

Combination of Islamic and Christianity Architecture. Combination of Islamic and Christianity Architecture.nice and great. don't go there without tour guider. you ought to know alot of history story about it.

Great History of two faiths.. This was originally a church in Constantinople that they changed to a Mosk after the Otoman empire took it over. It still has some original church markings as well as Muslim Mosk markings. A must see.

A peaceful working mosque monument. Don't miss this small yet working mosque with beautiful neighbourhoods while you do the big ticket items in Istanbul. The carpet and decor is beautiful as is the mosque peaceful.

smaller agia sophia but just as beautiful!. after seeing the extrodinary agia sofia....walk further down straight pass the blue mosque on a bit of a down hill ask around and they will tell you!... its totally free and its beautiful and i think its older than the agia sofia its self...it was peaceful and absolutley beautiful....around the area there are a lot of little restaurants and good eats!...

Loved it - Baby Aya of Sophia. This is a good example of a mini Aya of Sophia - Built in the Byzantine period, older than Sophia, relatively close to the bigger Sophia, its free, and a short walk through the Arasta Bazaar then keep going a few more blocks. Very peaceful. When I was there, I was all alone and no other tourists. No food at the site, but around the site there are lots of cute places to eat.
good a place. great a place and free if you near there you must see this place when you going to istanbul we went to there many times great a place....
Keep time for this one. Smaller but older n tucked away so no crowds n line n big ticket enterance!!! Anf just the walk there will show u other stuff
Peaceful place. Fantastic place with a lot of history.Built during the byzantine period, Occupied by the ottomans who kept Christian paintings and mosaic intact.

A place to see for all Aya Sofya fans. Our guide informed us that this building was constructed as a sort of trial run for Hagia Sophia and you can really see it when you visit. As the others said, this is a mosque, so wear appropriate clothing and avoid prayer times.

A quiet peaceful visit.. A quiet visit to a beautiful, decorated mosque. It is worth seeking this place out as it is devoid of the crowds elsewhere. The small artisans' quarter nearby is interesting too. You can also get a glass of tea here too.
Nice and free. Nice camii and free we love it this place down küçük Ayasofya and beautiful place if you near there you must go see this place and free :) very good a place...

Wonderful Opportunity . This is an active mosque so be sure to check prayer times ahead of schedule and ensure appropriate clothing - safest with long trousers and a loose fitting top (for females), a scarf to cover your hair is also required (again, for the ladies). There are scarfs and cloaks available to borrow inside. Expect to remove your shoes too, I left mine outside with no issue.It was my first trip to a mosque and I was a little unsure (worried to ignorantly offend if I'm honest), but it is a quiet area away from the hustle and the 'process' for visiting is clearly marked out on helpful signs to allow you to get on with it respectfully.It's a beautiful building and quite old - I specifically visited in order to see the Byzantine frieze that runs beneath the gallery inside. Amazing.It was also a great education.There is no charge for visiting active mosques, but donations are welcome - there is a box for this just after the cloakroom.
Not a "must-go" place. Kuchuk Aya Sofya mosque is just nearby Ottoman Hotel Park that we stayed. Nice mosque but nothing to compare to Aya Soyfa in Sultan Ahmet square
Absolutely worth a visit - and it is FREE. Absolutely worth a visit. Entrance is free. You have a feeling that you are in a sanctuary. Clothes are provided for tourist for appropriate entry.
Hidden gem. Another hidden object from organize tourism, but if you want to see one of Istanbul gem - please visit it, small but very nice. Near is very good restourant
Ayasofya Mosque and church.. Where peace and love are present between the religions. Not to be missed a visit to such a beautiful peace of art.

Nice place conveniently located close to the Blue Mosque. This so-called "small Saint Sophia" is located at the southern border of Sultanahmet, close to the Marmara Sea, not far from the Blue Mosque. It is much less crowded than more central attractions, and it is really worth a visit: it's quiet and well kept, with a nice inside and an external colonnade.
Amazing architecture. This temple is a real human miracle. I think this is a place that everyone has to visit in Konstantinopolis.

Ancient "Church "Mosque. Behind the Blue Mosque and through the Arasta Bazaar you will come into KucukAyaSophia Caddessi. At the end of this road you will find a The small Ayah sophia Mosque which was originally a church. The design is based on the big Ayahsophia. The interior is as spectacular - white marble and beautiful artistry and architecture. Do go up the stairs for views from the top. even though the interior has been restored upstairs but covered with protective glass you can see parts of the original brick wall structure. Note the peculiar water pump and spout inside at the bottom of the stairs. Great architectural and historical significance. please spare the time to go and see this structure. you will not be disappointed. If you have more time to spare and then take a walk to Yenikapi fishing harbour not far.

A peaceful haven and a beautiful mosque. For a real spiritual feeling, visit this mosque that served as a model, they say, for the Aya Sophia. Once a church, it has been better converted to a mosque than many others. Not crowded and beautiful architecture.

A must to see before visiting. Sergios Bachos Church or Küçük Ayasofya Camii. Has the basic plans of Main Hygia Sophia and Many other cathedrals in Europe as well. I guess it is too far from its originality but is worth so see before visiting the main Wonderful One. If you have time ask Giritli Restaurant which is not too far and have a taste the plenty of mezes.
Eclectic interior.. Bright little mosque that offers eclectic interior. Some of the columns are particularly interesting as they date from Byzantine time.

Easy to Miss. We found this former church while searching for a recommended restaurant. It may lack the majesty and grandeur of its more famous sister and does not have any mosaic frescoes, most of the Christian symbols having been obliterated, but it still impresses with its original marble column and interior sereneness. Headscarves are mandatory but available on loan. Be sure to have a glass of tea in the courtyard which seems to be a bubble of calm, perhaps the legacy of centuries of faith & prayer.
I want to go there again. One of the main reasons i visited Istanbul was to visit Ayasofya, very beautiful indeed. I was unlucky the place was under maintenance, i have to go there again

Little gem of a mosque. I love this little mosque. I always go to it when I am in Istanbul, as it is a happy little building, light and bright with it's blue and white colors that make it look like delft blue and white pottery. There is a little tea garden in it's front yard, and several artists have set up their shops there. The art in the tea garden is exquisite, and you will not find such high quality pictures and jewelry in the bazaar.
An oasis of calm.. A hidden gem, near enough to the centre and yet uncrowded and peaceful. Helpful staff. Must go back again to this small but perfectly formed haven.

Lovely. A bit further from the big Aya Sofia and far from the crowd, the little sofya is one of the loveliest mosque to visit. It used to be formerly a christian church, superbly redecorated. One of our most touching visits in Istanbul.
Not to be missed. This mosque/church is not be missed when you travel to Istanbul. Also the site is beautiful at night if you go have a drink on the Four Seasons roof top.

thr most important building of the world. Its a little bad that is not quit finished restauration,considering that is one of the most important building of the world.Dont forget thats created in the V-th century,(with 1000 years older than Blue Mosque,another capodopera) and ist a litlle bad also the religional revendications,....that building is creeated from the bysantines,.....not ortodoxes or not muslims....

Best Kept Secret. Visited on 3 July 2015 and saw the evidence of coversion of the church into a mosque:-i.e. the prayer mat and the side walls were slanting. Normally a typical mosque will have side walls aligned to the "kiblat" - direction of Mecca.

if you have time please make the effort. not far from Blue Mosque and no crowds when we visited. A lovely building with a lot of history (a very different experience to the madness of Hagia Sophia and Blue Mosque). If you can afford it, please leave a donation to upkeep this historic building.
Hmm, probably my favorite moscque. it is gorgeous but understated instead of the usual clash of patterns and colors. And it was less crowded too.

Multiple layers of history. One suggestion: take a guide. Make him take you to the second floor as well. There is so much history in this place that you need someone to guide you. Alternatively you could use the audio-guides available at the entrance.
Beautiful mosque. I very much like this tiny mosque however it looks very simple and quiet but has a lot to present. There are different type of architectures in this building.

Rich in History and still standing through the millenia.. Glad we hired a guide as she was able to circumvent the long lines. a lot of the interior was under scaffold annoying but necessary to make sure great buildings do not deteriorate. The size and history from Christian to Moslem to Museum make this a worthwhile visit.

The draft for Aya Sofiya. Before the building of Hagia Sofiya/Aya Sofiya the Byzantine emperor built this much smaller church to test the novel ways that had been worked out to support the dome. The Turkish name means "Little Aya Sofiya mosque." The church is still used as a mosque, but has been lovingly maintained and restored. A "must see."

Great place to visit!. Amazing place with a very rich history! Some renovation is taking place though so some areas are closed but you could still enjoy the visit. Beautiful collection in the upper floor with a chance to purchase some items at a higher price. The outside court is amazing where you could buy corn and bread and feed the birds or just sit and enjoy the scene.
