Easy Way to Pick What attractions to stop off and visit. Had seen Istanbul main sights on last trip so decided to venture out further from the centre on this bus. The city streets are a nightmare of traffic, just like any big city, The tour is scheduled for 1.5 hours but will probably take 2.5 or more because of the traffic. We chose the sights to HO HO on both routes. We were there for only 1 day on a cruise and stop 4 is just outside terminal gate. Not at all bad given the city traffic and Turkish organisation. You get what you pay for.

A good idea, but no fun in trafgic and rain.. Don't buy your ticket online. We understood it to be cheaper that way, but it was definitely MORE EXPENSIVE online!! Also, you are stuck with your purchase then and can't choose to do something else on a rainy day. We sat in traffic for hours, and were only able to get off once at the Dolmabahce because of the lengthened time in traffic. If I could do it again I would take the Istanbul ferry there instead for way less money.

A Must-Do in Istanbul. The Big Bus tour is always a must in exploring a new city. It's best to do this during your first few days in Istanbul. You get to see an overview of the city in a short amount of time. We did both the red and blue line which took us to both the Asian and European side of Istanbul. I enjoyed crossing the Bosphorus bridge, which is one of the 2 bridges that connects Asia and Europe.The bus had an audio guide which explained key landmarks and monuments as you pass them by and they also offered free wifi onboard which was really a plus factor. You can upload your pictures taken from the bus tour instantly. Since this is a Hop-On Hop-Off, you might want to plan your day well and try to get off in key places and catch the next bus which comes every 30 minutes. The bus tour starts at 9am and ends at 6pm.

Wow! Superb... Hoped on this right out side the Cruise terminal.
We traveled right over the big bridge into Asia.
This tour is hop on hop off... but we took the ride all round and dint get off much.

a good way to see everything in a short period of time. we enjoyed the tours (both the red line and the blue line) and I truly believe it is a must in the first days of your stay - you can easily take a quick look of everything and then decide what you want to see or where you want to stop; plus, it is a hop on hop off.They also have wifi on the bus which works very well and they also have an app which has all the details of all the points of interest on each route - just in case you missed it when the audio guide explained :)The thing that annoyed me was that in some parts the driver would drive too fast so the audio explanation would not match the buildings we saw and then, in other parts they would just drive extremely slowly ....
Big bus. always do a big bus tour in a new city as it give you a taste of what you would like to do and see. Good value.

Relaxed tour of Istanbul with a good view and with discretional stops. Hop-on Hop-off buses are very popular and available in most big cities of the World, so I will not enter into the details of the system and its advantages-disadvantages. For us is always a good way to get around the city with perfect view from the open upper deck of the bus and then stepping out to visit the attractions you want at your own pace. Clearly the bus tour is not a substitution to walking through the streets of Sultanhamed or Taksim! The ticket is cheaper if you buy it online (www.bigtours.com) and we took the 48h option which was only 5€ extra. The best is (if you have the time) to do the two available tours in two days. In the Red Tour as a minimum I recommend to step out at the Galata Bridge /Egyptian Bazaar to inmerse yourself with the crowds in the markets, boat restaurants at the piers and to enjoy the view of the New Mosquee and Topkapi. The other stop Taksim with the interesting area, where you can take the old tram of Istiklal commercial street. The Blue Tour repeats the Sultanhamed part and then goes into the Golden Horn. I recommend to step out at the Cable Car and enjoy the view from the top (see photo). If you are with kids you probably should stop at the Miniature park and at the Museum.We did not have very good experience with the Istanbul taxis, they manipulate the meter or ignore it, drive fast and few of the drivers spoke english so I could not recommend a taxi as an option versus the Big Bus. The public transport is modern and works perfectly with the Instanbul card that you should purchase in advance, we used it as well, but also not a real competitor with the Hop-on Hop-off. Trams are packed full with people most of the time. As extra I would recommend you board a ship for a round tour on the Bosphorous in the late afternoon. (I wrote also a review)

Probably better ways of transport. Ok I'll be honest, these open bus tours isn't my thing so a bit 'unfair' to give them a review. Still we ended up with a two day ticket. The red route is an ok way to get around, but because the narrow lanes everywhere the route is limited. Still it gets you between taksim area and sultanahmet. Still amazes me though why they always have so dull commentary?!? Me 'favourite' quote being 'Turkish coffee used to be called just 'coffee' until they introduced instant coffee in the 1980s'! The blue route is pretty pointless. On hindsight I'd stick with metro and taxi next time

Great way to see the city. We bought the 48hr tickets instead of the 24hr ones as the extra money is well worth it for the flexibility offered (so long as you are there long enough and likely to use them of course). The first time round we didn't get off, just experienced the complete tour which was awesome. I am terrified of heights so the trip across the high bridge was a nightmare for me, but I went downstairs and put my scarf over my head for that section. When you have an idea of the different areas you can get off and re-join after looking around - a fantastic way of seeing the sights.

Great way to see the city!. Having only a few days in Istanbul, we used the Big Bus Tour to see as much of the city as possible. The red route was great; we visited Taksim Square and hopped off for lunch at Hard Rock Cafe. Was also lovely to see the views of the Bosphorus and cross over to Asia. We also did the blue route, which has some great hop offs for kids. If we had more time we would have bought the 48 hour pass and used a day for each route. Great value way to see this vast, diverse city!!

Good over view of the city. This is similar to other cities in that you can at reasonable cost get a good over view of the city. Traffic is difficult but they have included time in the schedule for the delays. The have WIFI available on the bus but get the password before you board from one of the persons at the longer stops. The drivers are not always able to communicate the password to you. They have the sites described in many languages with a good description of the major sites.

Highly recommend . Big bus tour covering most of Istanbul sight seen with recorded guide in all main languages , you will have the chance to see all main places of Istanbul.Highly recommend as a first thing to do when you step in Istanbul with no earlier plan, then you can have a tour last for 2:30 also you can use the ticket for 24 hours starting from the day you purchase.Visit big bus tours web site

Another good Big Bus tour. This is the fourth city we have taken a Big Bus tour in (others were Dublin, Dubai, Cape Town S.A.) and it provided a great overview of the city that we expected. These are very good tours to take on your first day visiting a city as they give you the "lay of the land" even when you may still be a tad jet-lagged.The buses run less frequently in Istanbul than other locations and in the summer that can be a hot wait for the next bus, but I recognize there are business decisions that need to be made.I did find the headphone jacks on the top deck to have very finicky connections on every occasion; you folks at Big Bus need to maintain these better, please.I'd recommend that you take these tours.

Awesome . Awesome stops and awesome staff! Very friendly staff which made us laugh a lot and joked nonstop. At the same time they were polite and never crossed the line. The ride in the red line around Istanbul took about 2 hours to complete except during heavy traffic, specifically, if you catch the last bus leaving at 6:30pm from Sultanahment then you will be stuck in traffic for about two hours guaranteed. Istanbul traffic sucks in the evenings. It took us 2 hours to get to Taksim Square from Sultanahmet and we were hurting from all the walking. All we wanted to do was get to our hotel and relax. I would recommend doing your sightseeing in the morning and then catching the big bus before rush hour.

Easy, reliable, great service!. For 100 TL you can take this bus around Istanbul. It picks up every 15 minutes but we never had to wait more than 3 min. FARUK and ISMAIL were exceptionally helpful and made us feel welcome. Definitely a great bus service and great for a low budget. You never have to worry about a taxi during the day.ENJOY Istanbul!! THANKS BIG BUS for making our experience special.

Worth Taking.. We were in Istanbul last week of July 2015. My husband saw a flyer about the bus and thought it would be a good idea to take a tour of the city in the beginning of our trip. He was right. We took the bus from Taksim square and the ticket was 100 TL/person. We sat on the top deck and it was so much fun. The bus provide you with earphones and you can listen to the recorded tour guide giving information about the city in different languages. The bus has many stops in its route and you can leave the bus and take it again in the same day. Unfortunately we didn't do that but it makes sense to get off the bus and on again to explore the different attractions.

It's a great time to visit a city when Lazy or tired. This tour in Istanbul is valuable only on red line. The blue line around the Golden Horn is really a waste of time as the all city is not very beautiful and this blue line goes in very ugly parts. It's just good to head to the cable if you want to take it and climb up the hill to have a general view of the city. Otherwise you lose more than one hour in traffic jam and nothing to see.The red line drive you everywhere is stunning in the city and you can see all in bus and hop off when necessary.

Expensive . The concept is good but the price is too high. We paid 160 lira per person for the walking tour. It's easier to get around by metro and the walking tour was nice, but not worth the extra money you would pay if you just went on your own.

Great way to take in the city. We were reluctant to do this trip based on many negative reviews about traffic and other things however we really enjoyed it! Had no traffic problems, never in a standstill and managed both the red line and the blue line in one afternoon with a stop for lunch in taksim square. The commentary was ok, gained a bit of knowledge, but the highlight was just seeing Istanbul at a glance. It was a sunday, and during Ramadan so I'm not sure whether this was a factor, but traffic was not a problem so don't let that out you off!

Not bad but not good either. The best thing is that it gives you an idea of where things are. The red tour has 10 stops and the blue 7. They cover the Europe side of Istanbul. Only one stop on the red tour on the Asia side. It would have been good to see a little more on the Asian side. The commentary on the bus is basic on the history of Istanbul and instead of music a little more history would have been better. It is still the best way to get your bearings and organise your time to see what interests you.

A great way to get an initial view of an amazing city!. If you want an overview of Istanbul this was the way to do it! The staff were really helpful and it helped us decide what we really wanted to spend more time visiting during our 5 days there.

Great way to see Istanbul. Our family of four took the Big Bus Istanbul in late July and thoroughly enjoyed the tour. There are two routes and it is no problem to do both routes in around 3 hours in total. The buses run to the timetable very well, and the commentary was of a good standard. The staff were also very helpful, and friendly. In Istanbul most of the main attractions are close together and best visited on foot but the Big Bus Tour gives you the opportunity to visit those outlying attractions. It also provides the main amazing way of crossing the Bosphorous Bridge.

Excellent , worth all the money that you pay 👍🏼👍🏼👍🏼. Excelent idea. We really like the time we spend in this trip. Both routes are carefully designed and well operated. Only half day and we visit most of the important spots of a big capital . That's quite impressive. Plus , we bought 2 day pass and took impressive pictures of Istanbul , travel around all the places that we want to see and shop around in several places without spending money for the transportation. We wait maximum 10 min for the next bus which is impressive with the heavy traffic in Istanbul. Definitely worth the money that you pay , you even get more if you use it wisely :)

Fabulous and comprehensive tour of the city. Very impressed with the Big Bus tours of Istanbul. It provided a perfect overview of the city with hop on and hop off options to all the great tourist attractions. The audio guide offers very valuable tips about Turkish culture and the bus was on time and child friendly - we had two kids and a stroller. We never felt rushed and it was not overcrowded. For a refreshing view of Istanbul, don't miss out on the Big bus tour!

Excellent value-for-money insight and introduction to Istanbul. It was our first day of five in Istanbul and we had planned an itinerary of places to see but then we saw the Istanbul Big Bus Tour. As I was recovering from a knee injury, this looked liked a ‘must-do’ for us and we chatted to one of the operators and got on board. There are two tours (Blue and Red) that take different routes and you can hop-on and hop-off any of the routes on any of the buses that are approximately every half hour and can use your tickets for 24 hours, not just the same day, all for 100TL (about £25 at time of writing).We started with a tour that took us over the Golden Horn, through Taksim and Galatasary over the Bosphorus to the Asian side then back along through Eminonou to Sultanahmet. Rather than hop-on and off, we decided to stay on and just take in the sights whilst planning where we might want to go later in our few days in Istanbul. We did the other tour later in the day around to the end of the Golden Horn and back then the next morning we did the same first tour and used it to hop-on and off at places of interest.The big bus is excellent value-for-money and rather than have a guide telling you everything, you simply plug in the free earphones into the back of the seat in front and this tells you exactly where you are and all about the location. You also get a free map and guide leaflet. You can pick up the tour in Sultanahmet Square and get on and off anywhere that it schedules a stop.We couldn’t praise this enough - value-for-money, tour, guide and a great insight into Istanbul. this is something that we did not know existed in Istanbul but are so glad we found it. Excellent throughout.

Good tour. It has some bad points, it has some good ones.The Good:- not having a car in Istambul stops you from seeing the big picture of the whole town. Big Bus takes you near all the important landmarks and lets you see the beauty of the town from the outside.-it has a "hop on - hop off" style so you can get off the buss, visit parts of town and get on it again to finish the tour.The Bad:-Istambul traffic makes the Tour very boring at times and the drivers here are crazy :-) Over all I loved it, the tickets have a 24 hours valability so you can use them 2 days in a row.Prices are slightly negociable so try lowering the 100 TL/person fees.You get audio guinde and Wi-Fi in the price.

Not to miss. We booked the tour from the hotel we were staying in. The price is fair. We used our ticket twice for both the red and the blue route for the24hrs allowed. We were not disappointed. We enjoyed it a lot. Although it was hot (39 degrees), the open roof was absolutely airy... Simply enjoy the view.

Fair tour. The hop on hop off is a great thing to do in a big city like istanbul. The audio informartion provided, albeit basic, will help you gt around.Here is what everbody should do before taking the big bus:1- You should have some information about the city like where is Sultanahmet, Taksim, Galata Bridge, Ortakoy, the landmarks etc... so you would know what to look for when using the big bus map and listnening to audio indormation.2- The big bus tickets are valid for 24 hrs or 48 hrs so if you are using this tour to go from landmar to landmark or museum to museum, plan it well as istanbul has very bad traffic on workdays and the queues at the main attractions are long.3- The best day to use this tour is on sundays since there will be no traffic and the bus wont be crowded.4- It is best to buy the tickets for big bus o line beforehand (even before arriving to Turkey) along with skip the line tickets to Hagia Sofia, Topkapi Palace, Dolmabahce palace etc... you save huge amount of money.5- If you plan to use also the boat hop on hop off tour, do it on another day.Ziad.

Big Bus Tour in East meets West. A must do, although we didn't get off but took in the full tours, enjoying the variety of each of the 2 routes. Value for money, and with negotiation received discount from vendor.

Big Bus Tours in Istanbul. Istanbul has good attraction area. The tour gave some good information, however, general information such as population number for Istanbul was missing. The staffs were having difficulty in communication with the tourists. Basically, language barrier was the main reason why they could not provide proper information asked to them. And they did not provide brochures for tourists as guide. While first tour was okay, the second was delayed like half an hour to forty five minutes. And in addition to this, no discounts given for tickets, cruise or museum. I recommend for first time visitorto Istanbul to use this tour to give general information about the city's interesting places.

If first visit, amust to take. Take the red and the blue tours, then next days go to the places you like by Tram or buses.It was useful for me.It gives me a feeling that i have been lived here before.

Take the red one . Typically it was raining when we boarded. Warm fat rain but still rain, though the driver rolled a cover along the roof so we remained dry upstairs while still able to get some nice footage. Hard plastic seats, but quite comfortable and a cheap pair of headphones which you shouldn't bother with as the commentary is terrible and consists mostly of 80s in-flight music. So, on with the tour. You're given a little paper ticket which is good for 24 hours and you board at Sultanahmet Square. The map you're offered is basic but serviceable and if you're heading to places like Taksim Square it's a good way to travel up there. The route is quite pleasant though the traffic near Tunel is bloody annoying and you may want to doze off as it is rather slow-moving along the uphill stretch. How you cope with small children I leave entirely up to you. By the time you cross into Asia you're pretty much done and once you're back onto the Europe side it's worth stepping off and taking a break. In one stretch it becomes a chore but combined with a few places to cross off on the tourist list it's a much more relaxed way to cross the city. The red route is for my money the nicer of the two routes but both are worth a run at some point. The drivers are good, as are the ground staff who do their best to help you when confronted with a problem and have a good degree of fluency in spoken English. As a standalone, it's a reasonable two odd hours. Combined with one or two stops for lunch or sightseeing the hop-on bus suddenly becomes an invaluable little tool for the two days you'll be using it. Very much worth investing in for the first timer with little or no Turkish words under their belt

Very poor compared to similar operations in other countries. Don't get me wrong; we like the hop-on-hop-off bus concept. It is a great way to quickly familiarise yourself in a new city. However the mob in Istanbul couldn't organise a rock fight in a quarry. Waited around Taksim Square forever just to buy tickets early in the morning and then later after finally securing good seats on the top deck, we were forced to change buses on to a more crowded bus without explanation. Waited around forever again to change routes. Pathetic commentary meant I just didn't bother with the earplugs after a while.

Crossing the Bosphorus. We did both lines over the course of two days and found it good value. The best bit was certainly going over the Bosphorus Bridge into Asia, especially if you are sitting at the top. Our almost 4 year old son enjoyed both trips. Commentary and info was pretty good although the music they play while there is no talking is rather loud. As an overview of the city, very good. If you want to get off at one of the less used stops I suggest you let the driver know - we wanted to get off at Transport Museum but he only stopped for a few seconds so we hadn't even got out of our seats before he left again!

Big Bus Tour - Red . We thoroughly enjoyed and recommend this tour (my Dad and I). It was very informative and comprehensive, covering all of the sights of the city and allowing us to hop on and off at our leisure. Staff were very friendly and helpful. We enjoyed it a lot and would recommend to anyone.

A great introduction to Istanbul. There are 2 tours with Big Bus Tours - the Red Route and the Blue Route. As the ticket was for 48 hours, we did one tour in the afternoon and the other the next afternoon. The Red Route goes up the east coast, over the Bosphorus Bridge and back. It was supposed to take about an hour, but with the traffic jams it took 2 hours. Maybe the morning would have been better.

Big Bus Tours Istanbul. The tour was excellent. It's a perfect introduction for travelers who are visiting Istanbul for the first time. Additionally, it makes it easy for travelers to travel between points in a supervised environment if they are not ready to be fully independent. The staff is helpfuland friendly. Being new to Istanbul and only having a day and a half to explore, taking the Red Line gave me a wonderful overview of Istanbul and its history and allowed me to easily decide what sites I most wanted to see. And then I could easily visit them because they are all in the Red Line route. Our suggestion: take the entire tour. Then take the bus back to the sites you want to visit. Enjoy...we did!!

City break. The big bus is great, takes you to all the right places, a great way to see the city, staff were very friendly and helpful. Even better the ticket is for twenty four hours from when you buy it so can be used again next day if you want to.Sue and Ali London

You Can Always Count on BIG BUS. Have taken Big Bus in many cities and have never been disappointed and Istanbul is no exception. Great value for the money. In a city with so many unique cultural locations, Big Bus gets you there, lets you visit each at your leisure and delivers you safely and in a timely manner to your next stop.Your best city tour option nomatter where you travel.Doug & Rowna Mathyk.

Ups and downs. The busses run more frequently than in other cities which is great.After 20 minutes usually there was another bus... The routes are good but the comentary almost worthless...very bad quality in german as well as english.The biggest issue was there where only 4 seats at the very back in the shadow, of course always occupied.Since almost every bus had 20 empty seats in the sun why not put the roof over the last 4-5 rows so people who prefer not to be exposed for 6-8 hours to this very strong sun can sit in the shadow??#Take a lot of sunscreen :-) with you!!

Holiday. This is an exceptional way to see Istanbul . There are 2 routes, on day 1 we took 1 route of from the Blue Mosque through the older European side through Istanbul to the Asian side and back. The 2nd day we done the main tourist sites. A great way to see Istanbul for $60'AUD

The most important bus for leisure traveller. I took 48hrs ticket and me and my family love it very much. Its not only give you transportation to the top pick destination but give you different experience and view exploring the great Istanbul. Might quite expensive but really worth it!!!!

Great idea for your first day in Istanbul!. I recommend this as one of the first things you do upon arriving in Istanbul; that way you can get the lay of the land and see places you may want to more time at. It's also a fun way to spend a morning when you're still a little jet-lagged. The views from the upper deck of the bus were terrific! We thoroughly enjoyed the tour, though the 2nd part that they talked us into where we had to transfer to another bus was unnecessary. It may have been good for people with kids as it took us over to the aquarium and Miniature. Also, for a few bucks added, you can get another day, if that's how you want to get around Istanbul.

Istanbul On Big Bus Tours . If you ever plan a short trip but would like to reach each place worth visiting Istanbul - Opt for Big Bus Tours. Tour starts from Sultan Ahmet park right between Hagia Sofia and Blue Mosque. Opt for the 2 hours of RED route tour first as it takes you along the Bosporous into Asia and then brings you back to Europe highlighting several points of interest midway. RED tour ends at Sultanahmet Square where you can board the BLUE route which runs along the Golden Horn and includes Miniaturk among others. Buses run every 20 mins or so and therefore you can always Hop Off & Hop On to visit several areas of interest enroute. Tickets cost approx 85Euro for 24 hours tour or 100Euro for a 48 hours tour pass for a family of four (2 adults - 2 children). Note: Keep the Tickets safely as you will lose any further rides if ticket is lost.Recommended!!!

Wonderful tour. Had an amazing experience on the big bus tour! The staff were very helpful and there were several buses available to hop on and off. The information about the history was informative and helped make the tour memorable! This is a must tour if you want to take in all the amazing sites of Istanbul.

Open air overview can be amazing value. If short of money go round to check out visits. I stayed mainly in Sultanahmet apart from big bus trips ferry trips and air con tram trips.If short of time use the red route most though either will take you to Galata Bridge with interesting places to eat and a fish market to wander through.red offers lots of places you want to get off.Visit Galata tower,look,eat in restaurant beside it which offers small plates of food from all over Turkey.Wonderful food & helpful staff. Tower had a queue as free to locals on Thursday. We went to Richmond Hotel(Google it) who have a beautiful restaurant on top but we're happy to serve coffee mid afternoon & open windows to facilitate photos. A better view and a lift & coffee.

Amazing Site Seeing Tour. This is the best way to see Istanbul. The staff are very friendly and accommodating and the various routs offer amazing sites. The views along the Bosphorus and the bridge are breathtaking and the audio describes all the historical facts surrounding such a wonderful city. I would highly recommend any visitor to Istanbul to take the Big Bus Tour! Thank you to all of the staff for making our trip memorable!

Great tour. Staff was really helpful and kind. We travelled on the Red route and the following day on the Blue route. It gives you a great feel of Istanbul. The buses were regular and the audio guide was informative. Good value for money.

Big Bus Istanbul. 48 hour ticket was $99 Canadian for two people, thru Viator. exellent tour with top quaity commentary in many languages. red line travels along the Bosporous, takes 2 hours and at Sultanahmet Square right next to Hagia Sofia, Blue Mosque, Topkapi Palace etc, it joins up with the blue line which loops up around the Golden Horn. Buses are every 20 mins or so and pass by vurtualy every location you'd want to see, including across the Bosporous bridge to Asia and back

I love the Big Bus in Istanbul. The Big Bus costs 100TL (about $37 dollars) for 24 hours and 115TL for 48 hours. It is an open air bus that travels to all of the key sights in Istanbul. It has a Red tour (about 2 hours) and a Blue tour (about 1 hour). You can hop on and off the bus depending where you want to go. The Big Bus comes around each stop every 30 minutes, so you don't have to wait too long when you are finished sight seeing. Also, they have a good audio program that gives you valuable information and history about key sights. It is much better than booking a tour with the many SCAM tours offered in Istanbul (i.e. they are overpriced, cramped in a small bus like cattle, and I believe the tour guides fabricate stories). Also, the English is perfect on the Big Bus audio program so you don't have to strain your ears with difficult accents. I was so much happier on the Big Bus than being scammed on the Grayling Istanbul Tour.

A great way to get your bearings in a HUGE City!. We did this off our cruise ship the day in Port and it was definitely worth the ride.I love the hop on hop off idea, complete with commentary in 8 languages you really can't go wrong.There are 2 routes though we only did the RED one. The added bonus was FREE WIFI on the bus, what a great idea.We then spent 4 days in Istanbul and knew what we wanted to see and whereabouts it all was.

losing the head in istanbul. oh my god so awful I cant believe it. paid our 100 lire each and jumped on for a sight seeing trip round this amazing city. Spent an hour and a half looking at a flyover whilst stuck in a traffic jam. We finally hit the bridge at over 50mph in an open topped bus. then got smacked in the face by low lying trees not to mention the 2" gap from one of the bridges. listened to the worst commentary imaginable. zero content and a plinky plonk musical sound track made by someones uncle. For petes sake, thousands of years of history and you think the local library is worth mentioning. If you own this bus service, I know you cant control istanbul traffic but at least get the audio commentary fixed by actually telling something of the history of this place and lose that utterly annoying sound track. Oh and cut the trees back before someone gets injured.

Great way to get a feel quickly for the main tourist sights!. We bought tickets outside the Blue Mosque on the day we wished to travel. There was no problem and everything was simple: printed ticket and English language guide.The Big Bus operates two routes: blue and red. It is suggested that you travel to an attraction and "jump off" and then rejoin after you have seen the attraction. On the first day we did not do this but stayed on the bus for the full tours. This was a very easy way to get a quick idea of the main attractions and the diversity of the city. On the second day we visited a small number of places.In our opinion it takes time to see the attractions so we felt it better to concentrate on the second day. On subsequent days we visited other areas seen on the "Big Bus" on day one.We felt that the tour was very good and we recommend that any person does the same.

Excellent way to see the beautiful city, with two routes. This is the best way to see istanbul. Plenty of stops and buses comes very frequently. There are two routes red and blue, so it's great. We did both routes they cover different areas of the city. I would recommend this.

Good to give you some ideas on what to do, but commentary could be better. Took the 48 hour ticket for big bus tour Istanbul costing 115TL. Like all big bus its a hop-on hop off system that takes you to all the major tourist attractions. Unfortunately there wasn't live English commentary which I would have enjoyed. There is a pre-recorded English commentator but his monotone voice put me to sleep. However the views are beautiful especially over the bridges. Little on the pricy side in my opinion, and be prepared to wait in traffic for a lot of the ride.

Top Banana!. Great value - great morning out! Buy one ticket and hop on and hop off the bus as you like - ticket valid for 24 hours. Two circular routes around the city - red and blue - both excellent - but if you only have time for one go for the RED route - you cross over the Bosporus into Asia and return!. Of all the activities we did in Istanbul we found this the most rewarding and really good value for money. Highly recommended. You also get earphones.

Convenient way to see Istanbul. We love the convenience of hopping on and off the Big Bus. Great route to see all the major attractions with frequent bus every 15-20 mins. Worth paying for the convenience than to figure out the tram system.

Big Bus Tour. One of the best things to do. we spent all day the first day and part of the second you have 24 hours so much to see first day was spent looking and only got off for lunch then joined the yellow line to see more. Next day went back to get off where we wanted to go

No idea where is good to go?... Get this Big Bus!. I am spending 2 days in Istabul, and being first time, I could not figure out the best path... I found the Big Bus close the Blue Musque... The personnel was kind and helpful. Great experience... Good way to capture amzing pictures without the stress of being by yourself in the public transportation. I paid in cash 115 TRL that by the current exchange rate is almost the same that you will pay on-line. As other reviewers, I think the audio in your language is worth every dollar.

Best way to make sure you see all the sights. We really enjoyed this tour - was a cheap and convenient way of getting to places we wouldn't otherwise have gone to - for example actually going over the Bosphorus Bridge into Asia. There are 2 routes, Red and Blue, this review is for the Red route. We picked it up on the second stop as was nearest our hotel and it is valid for 24 hours so we knew it would go back to stop 1 anyway. Istanbul is notorious for its traffic but at least on the bus you're out in the sunshine (or downstairs in the air conditioning) and not on the smelly and crowded trams/buses. The earphones provided mean you can listen to descriptions and information in any one of 7 different languages. We found there were a couple of earphone ports that didn't work so you have to check that as soon as you get a seat in case the bus fills up and you miss out on the content. I would recommend this tour and do it again if we visit another city where these operate.
Great tour. Best way to see this great city. Look for uniformed staff is my only advuce and ask for the free wifi code when you join the tours.

Good and easy way to see Istanbul.. Well informed tour, went on twice on 24 hour. The only thing is when is traffic jam then the tour takes longer time. Good for people who have limited time spent in Istanbul.

Good but expensive tour..,.. Classic Big Bus Tours like other ones in Europe making very good service to main touristic attractions but it is also expensive.İf you also consider heavy traffic on its route,it is strongly recommended to make this tour yrself by using very good and convenient tram,metro and boat services at much lower price level.

best way ever to spend a day of leisurely sightseeing. I think the 100 Turkish lire spent per person for the 10 stops on the Big Bus Tours is worth every cent.The commentary you receive in your preferred language is a major plus,the fact that you can get off anywhere en route the 10stops at major attractions and get on again ,since bus are available every half hour at any of the stops gives you ample time to explore at leisure.I enjoyed the vist to Taksim square since lots of shops were open there it being Sunday today,at the atmosphere is rally touristic.The Spice Bazaar provided amazing bargains,and the beautiful scenery all the route was breathtaking

really good way to see the city. we did the 24 hour pass - and it was excellent. it's a great way to see more of the city - and to get your 'bearing' as to where everything is. Be careful and if you're on the top deck - WEAR SUNSCREEN - we fried!!!the red tour is FAR more instersting than the blue route.
Rip-off. 100 lira per person. Get a good pair of walking shoes and use trams and buses to cross the Bosphorous.

Very well informed tours!. These tours provided very much information - rich in culture and history. Pity that a large chunk of the tours overlap - it would have been great to have a little less overlap. We did both in the same day (had little time), and I would go again, if only to have some time to stop at some of the attractions!

Easy touring!. Affordable and easy way to see the city and surrounds. Watch out to only buy your tickets from uniformed staff, there seems to be other people trying to hussle in on the booking. The red tour is scenically beautiful and covers all the attractions. Blue tour possibly more for a family with children as you can do aquarium etc.All round a great stress free way to get see Istanbul.

Must do.. Istanbul is such a big city and if you don't know much about this city this is the perfect way to start your visit.There are two routes but probably the best one to start with is the red one. This takes you past all of the better known Istanbul landmarks.Once done you can then plan your visit better as you have all your bearings as to where sites are. Recommended.

Expensive and unreliable. The only reason I booked the tour was because it was raining heavily and I wanted to see a few sights. It was €60 for 2 of us which would go a long way in Istanbul. They didn't stick to the timetable so it meant standing around in the rain waiting for the bus to arrive. Wouldn't recommend it. Hire a driver or get the tram

Great way to see the city. The bus tour is a great way to see attractions that are not within walking distance and get more historic overview of the city. My husband wanted to get to see Istanbul beyond the old city. We hopped on and did both tours (Red and Blue). You will need to hop onto a different bus for each route. It is worth the money. Download the app for Big Bus on your smart phone or tablet, so you have a map and see the various hop-on/hop-off locations. You can purchase the tickets at a discount through the app (but not on the day of). We were able to purchase tickets, using a credit card, when we got onto the bus. We preferred the Red route, while we thought the Blue Route was a waste of time. There are a few mosques and Churches on the blue route if this interests you. Once you get on for the first time, they give you ear pieces for the audio tour, which is included in the price of the ticket. I used my own headphones, which worked fine. Though on the first bus, the audio cut out completely and I had to push the button to start the audio again. (This did not happened to my husband, who was sitting next to me.) If the music stops, push the button again and change the channel to your language. (FYI: Each bus might have English on a different channel.)On the Red Route, it includes going over the Bosphorus Bridge twice (going both directions). The day we went over it, it was really cold, windy going over the bridge, despite the really warm weather everywhere else. Bring something warm and protect your eyes (especially with contact lenses). If there is traffic on the bridge, it can feel like it takes forever to cross.

Great way to see Istanbul. We boarded the Big Bus at Sultanahmet Square. Staff was helpful and greeted us with smile also were provided with a route map and earphones. Tour explained in 7 languages. Started through Sultanahmet, to Galata bridge, Beyoglu, Besiktas, Bosforus Bridge, than through Taksim back to Sultanahmet Sq. It was absolutely enjoyable ride. Given information about various buildings, Mosques, and the area. Free wifi on board ask staff for password. You can also buy 24 hrs or 48 hrs tickets hop on - hop off at various site - the best way to visit different sites all over Istanbul.

Perfect for a whistle stop tour. We took the red route open top bus from outside the Blue Mosque/Aya Sofia. It was ideal for getting to see much more of the city than you could cover on foot. The roads in Istanbul are a nightmare given the level of traffic but the bus navigated the chaos quickly. This route took us over the bridge to the Asian side but it did get a bit chilly so take a jacket. The ticket is valid for 24 hours so you could also take the blue route which goes round the Golden Horn. The bus has a good free wifi service and the commentary is available in 8 languages. They will give you a free map to follow and you can also download the app.

covers a lot of ground, but beware of ticket problems. There are two choices of tour route, we took the red route. . You are provided with an earpiece which you plug into the socket and then select your language channel. currently 4 is English. My plug in point was not working but luckily there was a spare seat, so I moved. The commentary was in clear and informative. BEWARE We bought tickets in the UK and printed off the voucher with the bar code but at the joining point they could not scan it and demanded to see the original e-mail that went with the order. Others in our party had pre-paid and taken their online option to have the voucher sent to their mobile phones - again the operators had no way of scanning this and wanted to see original e-mails. So have both with you - or both saved to your phone. My husband had to open his e-mails to retrieve our confirmation there and then. Of course the phone then downloaded everything including work e-mails, junk etc and we were charged by the mobile company for each and every one! This happened to loads of people and there was a lot of delay and frustration,Something to bear in mind is traffic jams around the city which vary, but are always present. If you stay on for the whole circuit you could be a while. Make sure you take a hat and some water, although the open top bus has a shade, they do not always pull it across. Getting off the bus was no bother although you need to keep an eye on the map to know wen you are approaching your stop as you don't get a lot of notice. Getting back on the bus can be tricky as they are often full and you are relying on people wanting to get off and explore at your stop, so you can get back on! We waited quite a while for a bus at Taksim Square and there was no shade and nowhere to sit whist you waited. Not a reason to avoid this option, but keep these things in mind and go fully prepared.

Not enough info. We have used Big Bus tours in Santiago, Chile in Hong Kong in Dubai but in Istanbul the waiting times are extreme and when the bus arrives it's full so you can't get on. We staid at the Marriott hotel Sisli so the closest starting point to get on the Big Bus is at Taksim square where we bought a 2 day ticket the prices are not cheap. We had arrived around 11.00 am on Taksim square on Saturday and had to wait for 1/2 for a bus to come then when it arrived we couldn't get on because it was so full nobody who leave and so many people where waiting to get on. They should make sure to have more busses running when they sell so much tickets. I almost was going to ask my money back if we had to wait much longer. This was only on our 1st day. In all the other places you would be offered a bottle of water here you get nothing. On Sunday we arrived around the same time on Taksim Square to take the bus for the Blue route as the Red route we did on Saturday. We went to the same place to wait for the bus as the previous day but when it arrived it didn't stop and went onto the square again it was so full and hardly any people getting off now they said that the streets had been blocked because a marathon had taken place in that area and the police had just opened the roads again for traffic. After some complaining again we got on the bus but found out that people had gone off left there things and returned so we had to stand up which should not happen. We were still lucky to be able to hold on to a railing a few stops further we could take seats then. We had never experienced such a chaotic situation like this on the Big Bus tour some drivers didn't check the tickets either. Hire some more people so the operation runs smoothly to avoid complaints.

Very informative. Take a tour around Istanbul on a bus (a double-dekker). The best option is to go with family tickets, which enables you to enjoy a discount. There are "blue" and "red" tour, as well as Bosphorus tour which you can get with a fair discount if you go for the whole package. The best option is to sit on the open upper deck and to plug in your earphones and listen. The audio is very informative. The bus will stop occasionally at some interesting places and you can disembark at your will. Every 30 minutes another bus comes along and you can hop back on and continue your tour. Just be sure to have your ticket with you at all times. You ticket is worth for 24 hours. This is one of the best ways to get acquainted with this beautiful city.

Nice but not the cheapest option available. We took a 2 day pass/ticket and were offered a Bosphorus tour for 10euro each. The red line is a must to do. We stopped at diff places and had a nice time. The bus runs every 30 min and is fairly on time ( istanbul traffic being considered). Please ask for headsets and free wifi password as they are not always offered. Staff could work on their customer service skills although we dint xpct much from them so it was ok. Cheaper options like trams are available BUT i would still recommend the bus as u get 2 hear the history of where u are at any given point of the ride. NJY UR day n trip.

I just loved it... We took a 24 hr big bus tour and it was a good experience. Since it was a website booking we got discount as well paying Euro 25.50 per person & our two kids below 6 travelled free. It started from the Sultanahmet square and we have to go to the cashier and get the receipt in the beginning. We went the blue route in the morning with the first bus at 9.15 am doing a hop off at Miniaturk and then back to sultanahmet and did the red route. And they are at the stops every 30 min and we didn’t have to wait long. Both routes are great and took us to all the main places including the bhosphorus bridge and both continents.However, the traffic on the Istanbul roads are hectic such that the red route took three hours and towards the end it got blocked and we all got down and walked to sultanahmet which was faster option. I believe the 48 hours is not required since most of the tourist spots are accessible using Tram T1 and furnicular for Taksim and it is cheap with Istanbulkart.

Not cheap but a good way to get about. A 48 hour pass becomes economical, and it appears to be to to the hour rather than to midnight. Maps are available at the front of the bus, as are head sets. Expect slow going in Istanbul traffic and some fumes, but it's a pleasant, slow moving city viewscape. Guide is very good, perhaps a little more history would be good. Red line can take two hours. Staff aren't very customer focused but are friendly. Last bus around six pm in summer.

Poor quality service . You can spend anything from 45 minutes to 90 minutes in any of the bus stops. They urged us to step in the bus and pay, no maps available for us... whole pay for a couple is 60 Euros...take that money, bargain with a taxi driver and get a customized city tour for 80 Euros...

Hop-On Hop-Off. Great way of seeing Istanbul at your own pace. They stop at all the right places and its cheap and comfortable. This transportation system allows you to go at your own pace and to stop and start as your please. Up top is open air and great views.I would recommend downloading the free big bus app - really helpful. There is also free headphones and wi-fi. What more could a tourist ask!

Mixed feelings...... Like others have mentioned here, I usually do a bus tour when first arriving in a city to help get my bearings, but in Istanbul, I spent time with a Turkish friend, so didn't end up doing the tour until my last day and a half...... on reflection this was a little foolish as I had already been to a lot of the major landmarks on the red tour (there are two lines to this bus tour) and the blue route I felt was rather poor.... As I only got off at one or two stops, to take a break, and eat etc, I didn't find it too bad getting a seat, or waiting too long for a bus, but I can easily see this would have caused problems if I wanted to get off at every stop. Fairly good recorded info and at least most of the ports worked but you don't get offered headphones you have to ask, same for the map. staff are just really interested in getting you to buy a ticket.... once that is done they kinda lose interest!

Was horrible. Although I have to confess that Istanbul was really crowded, this bus operator is the worst I have ever experienced. Absolutely no organisation, oversold the buses totally. There were fights at the bus stops, endless queues or buses were not coming. In the end we never go on the bus.

Big Bus tour - mixed feelings. Like so many others, we like to take a bus tour to get the feeling for a place - especially when we only have a limited time in the city. We did this with Big Bus tours.The spiel sounded good - buses every 20 minutes, get on/off at any of 11 stops on a large circuit that takes two hours to complete. We were aware that we we got on the bus (Tacsim square) was very busy - but, after a bus hadn't arrived after 50 minutes, we began to suspect the worst. When it did come, our fears were confirmed. The traffic was a nightmare. The bus was overloaded (people standing) to get them out of the Tacsim area as the queue there had grown to over 50 people.Little changed for the rest of the tour - yet they were still selling tickets at several stops using the same line .... bus every 20 minutes etc. We didn't get off at all for fear of not being able to get back on ! - people were left behind at most stops because the bus was full.I really think that there should be a capacity that they work towards based on the number of buses they have - especially when they know the city is exceptionally crowded and traffic was at a virtual standstill at every major attraction.It turns out there were 4 cruise ships in port and it was a Saturday of a long weekend so big crowds were understandable ..... but all they seemed to be interested in was getting as many people on as possible rather than providing a reasonably comfortable experience.

Great way to see Istanbul. We bought a two day bus pass and received a discounted guided morning tour of the blue mosque, Sophia Hagia and the Grand Bazzar. It is worth getting the two day pass as it is only €5 more than a one day pass. You get headphones which you plug into your seat: the audio commentary is in several languages and it seems to be controlled by GPS. So you hear about the sights as you approach them. We did two different tours with them over the two days. You can hop on and off the buses which run every 20 mins to half hour. From morning to early evening.

Perfect for first time visitors. In every city that I visit for the first time, I take a kind of bus tour, to get the first overview of the city. In Istanbul there are two routes (red and blue), initially we paid only 24-hours ticket, but there was no problem to upgrade to 48-hour. I even got a really fast response to my e-mail question about upgrade possibilities. What you have to be aware of is the time that you need for the whole tour. We took a blue tour on Sunday afternoon, and it took us more than two hours to do only a half of it, although the whole tour should last one hour. But we were not in a hurry and it was really interesting to observe local families having picnic along the route.

Big Bus Tour is another great way to experience Istanbul. Very friendly staff are waiting for you close to the Blue Mosque or other locations in Sultanhamet District.With magnificent views from an open-top bus, Big Bus Tours Istanbul is a safe, relaxing way, and the perfect introduction to the major landmarks and historic sights of Istanbul.You will be provided with a pair of headsets to listen to the personal recorded commentary explaining the history and culture of this beautiful city in your choice of 8 languages.There is also Wi-Fi on the bus (how convenient, while being stuck in traffic - which happens quite often - to be able to look online at where you will go have dinner or what you will visit tomorrow?) !!!You can choose to do the Red Line first or the Blue Line (approximately 2 hours without traffic each) in order to have a good overview of where you would like to really visit on foot later. You have many convenient stops where you can hop off and get back on every 15 minutes or so.e-tickets are conveniently sent straight to your smartphone, so you wont have to print your ticket before you board the bus. You can also download the free Big Bus Map and/or App onto your SmartPhone by visiting their website at www.bigbustours.comThe hop-on, hop-off will enable you to hop-on and off the bus at many attractions and places of interest. Choose from a 24 or 48 hour ticket to see the city and its sights at your own pace. You can also choose to combine this service with a Walking Tour to visit Little Hagia Sophia, Topkapi Palace and its Hagia Irene Church, or another great option is Entrance to the Hagia Sophia, German Fountain, Hippodrome, Blue Mosque and the Grand Bazaar.Tour highlights include the journey from Europe to Asia across the Bosphorus Bridge, the Blue Mosque, Dolmabahçe Palace, Galata Tower and much more. Don't forget your camera to help capture some memorable moments !!!

See Istanbul. Big bus was a great way to see the sights and then decide which ones to investigate further. I did both blue and red routes, both have their significant places. Big bus staff very friendly and helpful. Would recommend the red route as covers the more historic places. 30€ well spent.
Good. This is a good tour but beware of the traffic - should take 100 mins but can take 200 mins - red route very good - dont bother with the blue route

Only for first timer who hasn't done homework. Personally i think its a very handy and practical alternative way of travelling around istanbul IF THERE WAS NO TRAFFIC which is quite impossible to be honest..The bus itself was comfortable, there's earphone provided which u can plug in front of you and listen to the whole history of istanbul and its mesmerising sights. Maps are provided to everyone. It comes every half an hour throughout important routes. 2 routes blue and red. Driver are helpful in assiting too.It's not fair to fault the bus really as they are just doing their job at their best but its the traffic that spoilt it all...

Great atmosfer. We were make a tour with big bus in istanbul and that's was really great that is good idea to make this company in Turkey . They have show as around istanbul how beautiful city we have thank you so much and by the way If you saw Mr Darren or Simeon say hi to them .

Spoiled by very rude driver!!!. Have just finished a 48 hour hop on/off with Big Bus Istanbul .Yesterday being 1st day we concentrated on the red route and have nothing but praise for the staff and experience, we hopped on and off all day,visited Grand Bazaar,Taksmin and more.Today we planned to see Blue Mosque and ride the blue route. We arrived at Taksmin around 10.15am and bus came about 5 minutes after.On arriving the bus had only 2 elderly passengers sitting downstairs, there were approximately 20 people waiting to board. My husband and I boarded and made to go upstairs only to find the upper level locked. Over the next 15-20 minutes we and many other boarding passengers asked the driver repeatedly if he could unlock the upper level only to be ignored or answered with abuse. Bearing in mind that todays weather was perfect for open bus travel we could not see the drivers objection???After a standoff lasting approximately 20 minutes the driver relented and finally opened the upper level,however it had clearly upset him and he drove like a man possessed for our trip to the Blue Mosque!!!Totally unacceptable behavior from driver which then made our previous experience on the 1st day pale with what we tolerated on the 2nd!!!

It was a good way to see the city but the journey took along time to go around due to trrafic congestion. We got to see all of the city by road and Boat.To purchase the bus ticket we had to go to the Sultan ahemat which was quite a track so it would be better to purchase the ticket on line before you go.

Big bus tour istanbul. A good way to see the further reaches of the city but disappointed by the lack of commentary guide. No earphones handed out and no explanation given.Also disappointed that the free wi-fi supposedly avaiable on board required a password which we were not given . Not one of the better bus tours I've been on

Nice way to see the city quickly . Used the service today. Both the red and the blue routes. Red one goes to the Asian side even, while the blue route is within Europe only. The bus has the multilingual Audio guide and the WiFi within. Is not the best way to see the city, but it definitely will take you to the places you would not go by your own, so is a nice tool to see the city quickly.
always the best way to travel. ive been on probally 25 big bus tours all over the world its a great way to see everything jump on jump off double decker bus free maps n headphones n prob 8 languages

Hop on hop off tour. Good red route tour. Bit expensive but good way to see different places. 30 € for 24 hrs. Bit cheaper if you book online 24 hrs before taking tour.Tip : Book online for 48 hrs tour.

Hop on ok stinky walk tour!. The bus was a great way to see istabul fast. Got hit a lot of place on the bus! Walking tour guide was ok but skip the German Fountain and just drop at the the doors to the grand bazaar!

Essential to understand the true scale and depth of Istanbul. Do this on your first day and you'll visit most of the iconic sites across this vast city. The Blue Tour takes you down the Golden Horn where you can see Europe's largest Dolphinarium and a fabulous Theme Park.The Red Tour takes you to Asia across the Bosphorus Bridge - truly remarkable (30 Euros for a 24 hour ticket for both routes)

Good overview. It was cold, with melting snow, but sunny when we boarded the bus at their Sultanahamet stop. Having just toured the Sultanahamet area until this day, we valued the ability to see more of Istanbul and to cross the Bosporus. Though the accompanying audio is available in a multitude of languages, something between the jacks and our ear plugs made listening a bit on-again,off-again. Nonetheless, we got a lot out of our red line tour. Caution: during the low season, traffic impeded the tour/timing.

Avoid!. We took the red route hoping to get around Istanbul fairly quickly to mark the places of interest that we intend to visit. Little did we know that we would be stuck in traffic for more than 2.5 hours in a freezing cold bus! We were told from the beginning that the whole tour is 2-hours long, yet when we decided that we'd had enough and left at Taksim, 2.5 hours were already wasted with not many sites seen.I would recommend taking a taxi cab and going directly to where you want.

Recommended. Big Bus Tours of Istanbul is one of the most convenient ways of exploring some parts of important sights of Istanbul for the ones who have limited time in İstanbul or Otherwise this is also a very good attraction to see the city from another angle while visiting the city.Recommended.

Big Bus Red and Blue Bus tour. We always try to find a hop on / hop off tour when we reach a new destination, it is a wonderful way of finding your bearings and learning about the places of interest you may want to visit in more detail. This one was no exception - we paid 90 Euro each, which admittedly was more than the brocure price, but it got us 48 hour tickets to do both the Red and the Blue tours with unlimited access. We did the Red circuit first - about 2 - 2 1/2 hrs depending on traffic and then the Blue route - about 1 1/2 hrs. The recorded information in English was a bit crackly - not up to the usual standard that we have come to expect - but very informative and we found the cable car on the Blue route, which we wanted to do but were having trouble finding, so that was a bonus. I would make a suggestion for more seating downstairs (only about 8 seats) as it was very cold having been snowing the past few days, they could also have put the plastic wind protectors down and drawn the roof across - but as this is mainly a summer destination, I imagine most people prefer to sit up-top. All in all a bit expendive, but a great way to get around and pick the places to re-visit.

Good Option on Limited Time.... Visited Istanbul while cruising on the Norwegian Jade and we stopped here on January 19, 2015. Right off the ship you are bombarded with dozens of people trying to haggle their goods and they are even intimidating at times since personal space does not seem to exist in Europe but once you get your bearings and realize that this is an enormous city and you don't have the time to try to figure things out quick enough. I would say this is a good option when time is limited. The price for a 48hr ticket was 30 euro each, which was actually just a couple of hours the first day since the ship docked late afternoon on the 19th but we still hopped on to get our money's worth and did the red route first which took us over the Bosphorous Bridge over to Asia and that was a neat thing to do and though the traffic was horrible that evening we stayed on the bus and kind of saw where we wanted to stop the next day. Next day came and we started early to make our day count and it was a pretty good experience since one stop pretty much leaves you at the main attractions which are the Blue Mosque, the The Sophia and the underground cistern and the world bazaar...The staff is not very helpful, they are always in a hurry and quickly dismiss you if you have a complaint as we observed a couple of people try to bring their issues with some staff members. In general it was ok, someone who is young and savvy can tour this city even cheaper using the tram but we are happy we used the Big Bus anyway. Istanbul is a beautiful place...

Should have been good. I usually like to take a bus tour for orientation purposes when I get to a new city, this should have been great BUT it was cold and snowy and the sides of the bus were down, sadly the plastic windows were badly discoloured, the glass windows filthy so you could not take pictures whilst travelling. Great in summer but then you fight with the thousands of other tourists to get on, c'est la vie!

Cognitively. You can use your ticket 24 (or even 48) hours. Big Bus provide you with headphones and map. Pay attention that this map is good only for Big Bus travelling, just to know where are the stations and their numbers, it is quite hard to use this map in purpose to find certain streets or places. Tickets can be bought online in advance.

Good for quick tours. A good way to go through Istanbul if you do not have a lot of time to spend touring attractions. It was a bit expensive compared to other cities in my opinion, but we got to see a lot more of Istanbul than we would have in the short time we stayed. The highlight was the drive over the Bosphorus Bridge.

A great way to see the city but be smart about stops!. A great way to get and see a lot of the city in what is a challenging place to traverse via road! Even with the extra day free only still had time to explore only the Red not the Blue (Golden Horn) route. Plan you stops carefully and strategically as I had a long, but still interesting last circle to get back with the afternoon traffic in Besiktas making it a 1-1.5 hour journey from the city centre back to Taksim. So be smart, even get off and walk or take/metro or fenicular rather than going all the way over the Asian side and back.Good views on the top deck and the commentary on the earphones is simple yet insightful. Be brave though and use the drop offs to explore of the main track!

Great Way To Tour. The hop-oh-hop-off bus tours are always our choice of doing city tours all around the world. They are very informative and comfortable and you can tour the city and sometimes much more (depending on routes available) at your own leisure. This worked best for us in Istanbul as well. We saw the best of both sides of the Bospherous Strait, European and Asian. You can jump from the red route to the blue route, exploring even more of Istanbul. In such a busy city, I would recommend this choice of touring.

Great Tour. I used this company in San Fransisco and they were excellent here as well. Wifi on the bus and very good assortment of places to hop on and off. I primarily rode it around the city because of time constraints. Would suggest it as it hits many highlights.

Well worth it. It costs 90tl(£25) and it lasts for 48 hrs.you litterally see the whole of istanbul. We did the red route one day and the blue the next. On the blue route you go over briefly to the asian side. You can hop on and off as you please. You are given headphones to listen to the guides explaing the history of the places on route. The staff speak perfect english and are laughing all the time. Highly recomended.

Tour of istanbul. We found this tour the ideal way to see Istanbul. We could get on and off at the famous landmarks of Istanbul taking our time to explore and experience this amazing city. We got off at Taxim square,saw Gezzi Park and walked down Istacalal, we took wonderful photos of the Bosperus as we drove over to the Asia side, and had panoramicl views of the city from the drive. We had a very informative commentry on personal headphones all the way so we knew what was coming up. The bus was punctual and the staff very friendly. We definitely recommend this trip.

Nice Way To Get Around. On our last day in Istanbul, we decided to take the Big Bus. It was a nice way to get around to see a few last minutes things. We took in a palace, Taksim Square, Holy Trinity Church, a couple of mosques and the Egyptian Bazaar. It is a little expensive, but for us it was a great way to get from the Asian side where we saw the palace all the way around to the bazaar.

Don't go for the boat tour. The bus trip itself is fine, but the boat tours they offer is terribly organized. The transportation to the jetty is weird, but this is not the worst thing. The tour ended not in the starting point, and no bus was offered to return us back, we had to walk to the nearest tram station. If you don't know the city well you may get in trouble.

not a good winter option. a nice way of getting around the city but the company should get their act together - many people have reviewed the poor conditions of the upstairs covers during poor weather. Tourism is still a major winter activity in Istanbul, something needs to be done

Don't go when it rains. We thought as it was raining we would go on the BIG BUS in Istanbul, also they charge 30 Euro a day but in winter it last for 48 hours. We went on the top deck as the downstairs there were no seats available. The plastic sheeting around the top deck had a lot of holes in it and when the bus started moving the sheets starting flapping letting a lot of rain and cold wind through. A lot of people went downstairs but you could not hear the commentary as there was no where to sit.

Expensive and less frequent. The bus ticket is expensive and its service is less frequent (once an hour) since it is off season. We could have taken the public transportation (cheap and more frequent) to see the places we wanted. On the other hand, if one is not able to walk to many sites, the bus is an option to see them from the distance. The upper deck is windy and cold so make sure you dress properly (and wear a warm hat!).

A bit expensive but convienient. They offer two routes, red and blue. The red one goes across to Asia crossing over the Bosphrous bridge and across many scenic points and important locations. The blue one goes to the new town and newer spots including some museums. The €30 pass is valid for 48 hours, so there's no hurry if you've got time. Also, there's free WiFi.

Bosphorus trip through Big Bus tour..... Today we went over to get a ride at the Big Bus stop number 1, and was told to come back in half and hour. We got at the stop number 1 again and was told the bus had left. And a guy told us that we have walk a little further to catch the transport to the ferry port. We had to walk in a rush for 5 mins and we were asked to board an already full bus. A while later more pax were asked to board. They do not bother about safety. When asked, they say they have problems. When on the boat, there were no safety life jackets and the boat was carrying in excess of it's capacity! Many were seated in loose plastic chairs and many were standing as well! I believe this is how tragedies happens!

A Great way to see a fantastic city. You really don't realise how expansive Istanbul is until you see from this perspective, it was a real eye-opener and I can't imagine any other way to see it than on the Big Bus tour - fantastic!

Great way of seeing the whole of Istanbul...well most of it.... We took the two day ticket, and did the Blue route, jumped off and did the Red route...and then decided where we would hop on and hop off the following day...We went to the Greek Orthodox Church, then onto the Cable Car and then visited Minature Turkey....but as it was winter, we then ran out of time. It was very comfortable on the upper deck, and although winter, we had two sunny days. We then had another 3 days to explore the rest of Istanbul by foot....oh yes the bus has free wifi....

What a fantastic journey.. We were on a cruise which called into Istanbul, a city I had always wanted to see. We spotted a Big Red Bus and got on it, the driver wouldn't accept any money, he told us to stay on the bus and pay when we got to Taksim Square, what a fantastic journey we had before we arrived back at Taksim Square. We saw the Blue Mosque,Hagia Sofia, Topkapi Palace, went on the Bosphorous Bridge and the Galata Bridge and even went over to Asia. We even had free wifi whilst we were on the bus. When we did get back to the Square, we were told the fare was 30 euros each which sounded expensive for 24 hours but we managed to fit another trip on the bus the very next day. After seeing plenty of traffic accidents while we were on the bus it seemed a very good and safe way of seeing Istanbul.

Easy and comfortable way to cover all important places in Istanbul. Big Bus Istanbul is a very comfortable and good way of sightseeing in Istanbul. There are two routes - Red Route and Blue Route. The buses run on an interval of 30 minutes. Both the routes are Circular routes, starts from Sultanahmet Square. You will cover most attractions of Old City like Blue Mosque, Hagia Sofia, Topkapi Palace by walking. The other attractions like Dolmabache Palace, Bosphorous Bridge, Beylerbeyi Palace on Asia side, Taksim Square, Galata Bridge and Galata Tower etc can be covered by Big Bus - Red Route. Red Route is the most important route. If you take a 48 Hrs Ticket, you can cover both Red Route and Blue Route. It is advisable to take the Red Route first as it covers most of Important attractions of Istanbul. Blue route will take you to the Golden horn trip. Please do not miss a cup of coffee at the Pierre Loti Cafe. You can enjoy a hot (or cold) cup of coffee with a breathtaking view of the Golden Horn. Very refreshing.

Good way to see alot. The traffic in Istanbul is a nightmare and the Big Bus gives a good alternative for transportation which takes you to the sights bypassing the congested routes which the tricky taxi drivers will use to make the fare more! There are 2 tours with option of 24 or 48 hrs. We took the 48 hrs ticket. Did the Red tour on one day and Blue on the next. With the traffic and if you plan to hop off at some sights along the route, it will take a full day to do one route comfortably. The buses are comfy, kids loved sitting on the top though its obviously quite windy and cold and there is a plastic covering which passengers can 'pull' up during rain. The audio guide is nice and clear. We were glad we did the tours.I would mention that during our Red tour, we waited around 1.5 hrs in the cold for the bus to come to the British Council stop near Istiklal St. because of the congestion. The helpline number wasn't responding so my husband sent an email and their by email response was quick stating that the bus was coming though held up in traffic!

Be prepared for a long, slow journey. This is a good way to see the city. There are 2 tours you can take which cover all of the city, even going for a quick visit to Asia. You can also add on a boat tour round the Bosphorous. The audio guide is clear and informative and you can hop on/off at various locations. The only thing that makes it a drag is the Istanbul traffic which is gridlocked, so you spend a lot of time waiting in queues.

Average / litlle pricey. Nice for having a round to most of istanbul attarctions . The main problem is the trafiic in Istanbul so you will feel bored while moving slowly in the bus. The plus point is that you can use the facility for 48 hrs and if you visiting any attrction you want you can just take the next bus and they have a separte bus-stop . Little overprice but as a first time visitor must try.

Good for transportation, not for information. The big maroon buses that crowd Sultanahmet Square are also rife with salespeople...there seem to be 3 salesmen for every bus! Too bad there wasn't more staff represented on the buses themselves as the driver is alone with the recorded "tour guide" which is adequate but they are not always synchronized and it's not easy to determine if there is or isn't a stop ahead. Some versions of this tour include a Bosphorous tour which we did take; it was a gorgeous day and a beautiful trip but I longed for more guide information! I had my book and read along with the little information the guide provided. However, the buses were clean and frequent. Istanbul is a very large city and the two routes are useful for getting a sense of areas such as Taksim, Golden Horn, etc. Finally, (and perhaps because the city is so big) this hop-on, hop-off is probably the most expensive I have encountered in either Europe or North America.

One city not worth seeing with the HO HO Bus! Walk or use the tram!. We have had some great experiences using the HO HO Bus in many cities. Istanbul is not a good choice for this bus. We were very disappointed with the inflated price and then we wasted 2 hours sitting in traffic on the bridge getting no where. The driver was clearly frustrated and entertained himself on his cell phone most of the time. If the weather is cool you can't stay upstairs and the seating and viewpoints downstairs are very limited. Istanbul is a wonderful walkable city where most of the main attractions are located. Use the fantastic tram system if you get tired.

A way to get around the city - slowly. We often use these sort of tours to get an overview of a city. They are pricey but if you have spent a lot of money to fly to a city you may as well pay some more and see as much as you can in the short time you have. Sadly, the traffic in Istanbul is a huge handicap to the progress of the bus and at peak times it can take a long time.We bought a two day pass with added boat tour online to save money. However, on the first day when we tried to locate the boat stop, which we thought was at the No 2 stop, we couldn't find it. It was only when we went to the number one stop, where their staff sell the tours, did we find out the boat left from a completely different area near the main square. Anyone wishing to go on the boat trip has to wait there for a guide who will then take you on a fifteen minute walk down to the mooring. Anyone with mobility issues may find the walk a little taxing. There were so many people in our group we decided when we saw the smallish ferry that we wouldn't most probably get a seat outdoors on the boat, so we gave it a miss.The blue route is a little dull apart from the stop at the Rahmi M Koc Museum which was a great attraction and should not be missed. Allow at least one and a half hours here. The red route is more interesting but sadly we went on a Thursday and two of the palaces we wanted to see were closed on Thursdays. If the driver had told us they were closed we would not have got off at that stop thus preventing us from having to wait another 30 minutes for the next bus. Not very helpful when most people only have a limited time in the city.So if you decide to buy a ticket check what places are open on the day/s you wish to travel on.

Chilly with lots of traffic. With such a beautiful city this should have been a great addition. The bus and it's driver are lovely but the traffic and the lack of historical context in the audio let it down. It was also cold - especially over the bridge and there was not enough space downstairs. But good value for using over two days we only had chance to do red line.

Too bad. I have to concur with the other folks on here, that this is a big expense and can be a huge timesink if you get on at the wrong time. We tried to get aboard in the late afternoon and ended up spending more than 3 hours on the bus just to get from stop 1 to stop 8. BIG loss of time to do other things because of this. And at 40 euro per person, it is a significant cost as well. Not a bad tour of the city and very informative, but be ready to sit there for awhile!

Great way to see the city. If your time is short, if you want to visit several sites in a day, if you want a good overview of the city then this is for you. You can make reservations on-line. get on and off as much as you want. There is a red tour and a blue tour. If you stay on the bus it will still be a two hour ride touring the city.

Not Worth the Money. I chose to do the Big Bus Tour in Istanbul today, as a way to get an overview of the city. And it did just that. However, the overall experience for me, was just a waste of 35 Euros. Granted, today was a cold, rainy and windy day. That said, there were pros and cons.Pros: it is a good way to see the city, and could be done early in your visit. There are different languages available. The hop on/hop off feature is good. The ticket includes a 24 hour period, and for an extra 5 Euros, that can be extended to 48 hours. But:Cons: This tour, I was told, takes about 2 hours per route. There are 2 routes, and the price includes both of them. I stupidly paid an extra 5 Euros to extend my ticket to cover 48 hours. We started out from Sultanahmet area, and from Karakoy to the large bridge over the Bosphorus, we sat in traffice for 30 minutes. At a standstill.
